titleStmt.title: The Second part of Henrie the fourth, continuing to his death, and coronation of Henrie the fift. With the humours of sir Iohn Falstaffe, and swaggering Pistoll. As it hath been sundrie times publikely acted by the right honourable, the Lord Chamberlaine his servants. [QB, containing 3.1 which is missing in QA]

respStmt.name: Kyonnah Price. Homographs and regularising by Alexis Antonia

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by V.S. for Andrew Wise, and William Aspley.

editorialDecl.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations.
King Henry IV Prince Henry; Son of Henry IV; later King Henry V Prince John of Lancaster; Son of Henry IV Prince Humphrey of Gloucester; Son of Henry IV Prince Thomas of Clarence; Son of Henry IV Earl of Warwick; King's party Earl of Westmoreland; King's party Henry Percy; Earl of Northumberland; King's party Lord Chief Justice Richard Scroop; Archbishop of York Edward Poins; Gentleman in waiting to Prince Henry Sir John Falstaff Shallow; Country Justices Silence; Country Justices Hostess Quickly; Hostess of a tavern in Eastcheap Prologue/Epilogue Multiple Speakers unspecified speaker Gower; King's party Harcourt; King's party Lord Mowbray; Opposites against King Henry IV Lord Hastings; Opposites against King Henry IV Lord Bardolph; Opposites against King Henry IV Sir John Coleville Travers; Retainer to Northumberland Morton; Retainer to Northumberland Bardolph; Irregular humourist Pistol; Irregular humourist Peto; Irregular humourist Davy; Servant to Shallow Francis; Another drawer Fang; a Sergeant Snare; his Yeoman Lady Northumberland Lady Percy; Wife to Hotspur; Sister to Mortimer Doll Tearsheet Rumour; the Presenter Servant to the Lord Chief Justice A Page; Irregular humourist Mouldy; Country soldier Shadow; Country soldier Wart; Country soldier Feeble; Country soldier Bullcalf; Country soldier Porter Second Drawer Messenger First Beadle; Sinklo First Strewer Second Strewer Third Strewer

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following

div1.head: The second part of Henry the fourth, continuing to his death, and coronation of Henry the fift.

div1.stage: Enter Rumour painted full of Tongues.

sp.l: OPen your ears; for&H3; which&H62; of you will&H1; stop
The vent of hearing, when loud Rumour speaks?
I from the Orient to&H4; the drooping West,
(Making the wind my post horse) still unfold
The acts commenced on&H4; this ball of earth,
Upon&H4; my tongues continual slanders ride,
The which&H61; in every language I pronounce,
Stuffing the ears of men with false reports,
I speak of peace while covert enmity,
Under the smile of safety, wounds the world:
And who&H62; but Rumour, who&H62; but only I,
Make fearful musters, and prepared defence,
Whiles the big year, swollen with some other grief,
Is thought with child by&H4; the stern tyrant War?
And no&H2; such matter. Rumour is a pipe,
Blown by&H4; surmises, Jealousies conjectures,
And of so&H51; easy, and so&H51; plain a stop,
That&H3; the blunt monster, with uncounted heads,
The still discordant wavering multitude,
Can play upon&H4; it. But what need I thus
(My well known body) to&H9; anathemize
Among my household? why is Rumour here?
I run before King Harries victory,
Who&H61; in a bloody field by&H4; Shrewsbury,
Hath beaten down young Hotspur and his troops,
Quenching the flame of bold rebellion,
Even with the rebels blood. But what mean I
To&H9; speak so&H51; true at first? my office is
To&H9; noise abroad, that&H3; Harry Monmouth fell
Under the wrath of noble Hot-spurs sword,
And that&H3; the King before the Douglas rage,
Stooped his anointed head as low as death.
This have I rumoured through the peasant towns,
Between that&H62; royal field of Shrewsbury,
And this worm-eaten hole of ragged stone,
When Hot-spurs father old Northumberland
Lies crafty sick, the posts come tiring on&H5;,
And not a man of them brings other news,
Than they have learnt of me, from Rumours tongues,
They bring smooth comforts false, worse than true wrongs.

div2.stage: Enter the Lord Bardolfe at one doore.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: Who&H62; keeps the gate here ho? where is the Earl?

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.l: What shall I say you are?

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: Tell thou the Earl,
That&H3; the Lord Bardolfe doth attend him here.

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.l: His Lordship is walked forth into the orchard,
Please it your honour knock but at the gate,
And he himself will&H1; answer.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: Here comes the Earl.

sp.speaker: Earle.
sp.l: What news Lord Bardolfe? every minute now
Should be the father of some Stratagem,
The times are wild, contention like&H4; a horse,
Full of high feeding, madly hath broke loose,
And bears down all before him.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: Noble Earl,
I bring you certain news from Shrewsbury.

sp.speaker: Earle
sp.l: Good, and God will&H0;.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: As good as heart can wish:
The King is almost wounded to&H4; the death,
And in&H4; the fortune of my Lord your son,
Prince Harry slain outright, and both the Blunts
Killed by&H4; the hand of Dowglas, young prince Iohn,
And Westmerland and Stafford fled the field,
And Harry Monmouthes brawn, the hulk sir Iohn,
Is prisoner to&H4; your son: O such a day!
So&H52; fought, so&H52; followed, and so&H51; fairly won,
Came not till now to&H9; dignify the times
Since Cæsars fortunes.

sp.speaker: Earle
sp.l: How is this derived?
Saw you the field? came you from Shrewsbury?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I spake with one, my lord, that&H61; came from thence,
A gentleman well bred, and of good name,
That&H61; freely rendered me these news for&H4; true.

sp.speaker: Earle
sp.l: Here comes my servant Trauers who&H61; I sent
On&H4; tuesday last to&H9; listen after news.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: My lord, I over-rode him on&H4; the way,
And he is furnished with no&H2; certainties,
More than he happily may retell from me.

sp.speaker: Earle
sp.l: Now Trauers, what good tidings comes with you?

sp.speaker: Trauers
sp.l: My lord, sir Iohn Vmfreuile turned me back
With joyful tidings, and being better horsed,
Out rode me, after him came spurring hard,
A gentleman almost forespent with speed,
That&H61; stopped by&H4; me to&H9; breathe his bloodied horse,
He asked the way to&H4; Chester, and of him
I did demand what news from Shrewsbury,
He told me that&H3; rebellion had bad luck,
And that&H3; young Harrie Percies spur was cold:
With that&H62; he gave his able horse the head,
And bending forward, struck his armed heels,
Against the panting sides of his poor jade,
Up&H5; to&H4; the rowel head, and starting so&H52;,
He seemed in&H4; running to&H9; devour the way,
Staying no&H2; longer question.

sp.speaker: Earle
sp.l: Ha? again,
Said he, young Harry Percies spur was cold,
Of Hotspur, Cold-spur, that&H3; rebellion
Had met ill luck?

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: My lord, I will&H1; tell you what,
If my young Lord your son, have not the day,
Upon&H4; mine honour for&H4; a silken point,
I will&H1; give my Barony, never talk of it.

sp.speaker: Earle
sp.l: Why should that&H62; gentleman that&H61; rode by&H4; Trauers,
Give then such instances of loss?

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: Who&H62; he?
He was some hilding fellow that&H61; had stolen
The horse he rode on&H5;, and upon&H4; my life
Spoke at a venture. Look, here comes more news.

sp.speaker: Earle
sp.l: Yea this man's brow, like&H5; to&H4; a title leaf,
Foretells the nature of a tragic volume,
So&H52; looks the strand, whereon the imperious flood,
Hath left a witnessed usurpation.
Say Mourton, didst thou come from Shrewsbury?

sp.speaker: Mour.
sp.l: I ran from Shrewsbury my noble lord,
Where hateful death put on&H5; his ugliest mask,
To&H9; fright our&Htp; party.

sp.speaker: Earle
sp.l: How doth my son and brother?
Thou tremblest, and the whiteness in&H4; thy cheek,
Is apter than thy tongue to&H9; tell thy errand,
Even such a man, so&H51; faint, so&H51; spiritless,
So&H51; dull, so&H51; dead in&H4; look, so&H51; woe begone,
Drew Priams curtain in&H4; the dead of night,
And would have told him, half his Troy was burnt:
But Priam found the fire, ere he, his tongue,
And I, my Percies death, ere thou reportest it.
This thou wouldst say, Your son did thus and thus,
Your brother thus: so&H52; fought the noble Dowglas,
Stopping my greedy ear with their bold deeds,
But in&H4; the end, to&H9; stop my ear indeed,
Thou hast a sigh to&H9; blow away this praise,
Ending with brother, son, and all are dead.

sp.speaker: Mour.
sp.l: Douglas is living, and your brother yet,
But for&H4; my Lord your son:

sp.speaker: Earle
sp.l: Why he is dead?
See what a ready tongue Suspicion hath!
He that&H61; but fears the thing he would not know,
Hath by&H4; instinct, knowledge from others eyes,
That&H3; what he feared is chanced: yet speak Mourton,
Tell thou an Earl, his divination lies,
And I will&H1; take it as a sweet disgrace,
And make thee rich for&H4; doing me such wrong.

sp.speaker: Mour.
sp.l: You are too great to&H9; be by&H4; me gainsaid,
Your spirit is too true, your fears too certain.

sp.speaker: Earle
sp.l: Yet for&H4; all this, say not that&H3; Percy is dead,
I see a strange confession in&H4; thine eye,
Thou shakest thy head, and holdest it fear, or sin,
To&H9; speak a truth: if he be slain,
The tongue offends not that&H61; reports his death,
And he doth sin that&H61; doth belie the dead,
Not he which&H61; says the dead is not alive,
Yet the first bringer of unwelcome news
Hath but a loosing office, and his tongue
Sounds ever after as a sullen bell,
Remembered tolling a departing friend.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: I cannot think, my Lord, your son is dead.

sp.speaker: Mour.
sp.l: I am sorry I should force you to&H9; believe,
That&H62; which&H61; I would to&H4; God I had not seen,
But these mine eyes saw him in&H4; bloody state,
Rendering faint quittance, wearied, and out-breathed,
To&H4; Harry Monmouth, whose swift wrath beat down
The never daunted Percy to&H4; the earth,
From whence with life he never more sprung up&H5;.
In&H4; few his death, whose spirit lent a fire,
Even to&H4; the dullest peasant in&H4; his camp,
Being bruited once, took fire and heat away,
From the best tempered courage in&H4; his troops,
For&H3; from his mettle was his party steeled,
Which&H61; once in&H4; him abated, all the rest
Turned on&H4; themselves, like&H4; dull and heavy lead.
And as the thing that&H61; is heavy in&H4; itself,
Upon&H4; enforcement flies with greatest speed:
So&H52; did our men, heavy in&H4; Hot-spurs loss,
Lend to&H4; this weight such lightness with their fear,
That&H3; arrows fled not swifter toward their aim,
Than did our soldiers aiming at their safety,
Fly from the field: then was that&H62; noble Worcester,
So&H51; soon taken prisoner, and that&H62; furious Scot,
The bloody Douglas whose well labouring sword,
Had three times slain the appearance of the King,
Gan vail his stomach, and did grace the shame
Of those that&H61; turned their backs, and in&H4; his flight,
Stumbling in&H4; fear, was took: the sum of all
Is, that&H3; the King hath won, and hath sent out,
A speedy power to&H9; encounter you my lord,
Under the conduct of young Lancaster,
And Westmerland: this is the news at full.

sp.speaker: Earle
sp.l: For&H4; this I shall have time enough to&H9; mourn,
In&H4; poison there is physic, and these news,
Having been well, that&H61; would have made me sick:
Being sick, have (in&H4; some measure) made me well:
And as the wretch whose fever-weakened joints,
Like&H4; strengthless hinges buckle under life,
Impatient of his fit, breaks like&H4; a fire
Out of his keepers arms; even so&H52; my limbs,
Weakened with grief being now enraged with grief,
Are thrice themselves: hence therefore thou nice crutch,
A scaly gauntlet now with joints of steel
Must glove this hand, and hence thou sickly coif,
Thou art a guard too wanton for&H4; the head,
Which&H61; princes, fleshed with conquest, aim to&H9; hit:
Now bind my brows with iron, and approach
The raggedest hour that&H61; Time and Spite dare bring,
To&H9; frown upon&H4; the enraged Northumberland,
Let heaven kiss earth, now let not Natures hand
Keep the wild flood confined, let Order die,
And let this world no&H2; longer be a stage,
To&H9; feed contention in&H4; a lingering act:
But let one spirit of the first born Cain
Reign in&H4; all bosoms, that&H3; each heart being set
On&H4; bloody courses, the rude scene may end,
And darkness be the burier of the dead.

sp.speaker: Vmfr.
sp.l: This strained passion doth you wrong my lord.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: Sweet earl, divorce not wisdom from your honour,

sp.speaker: Mour.
sp.l: The lives of all your loving complices,
Leave on&H4; you health, the which&H61; if you give over,
To&H4; stormy passion must perforce decay.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: We&Htp; all that&H61; are engaged to&H4; this loss,
Knew that&H3; we&Htp; ventured on&H4; such dangerous seas,
That&H3; if we&Htp; wrought out life, it was ten to&H4; one,
And yet we&Htp; ventured for&H4; the gain proposed,
Choked the respect of likely peril feared,
And since we&Htp; are overset, venture again:
Come, we&Htp; will&H1; all put forth body and goods.

sp.speaker: Mour.
sp.l: It is more than time, and my most noble lord,
I hear for&H4; certain, and dare speak the truth.

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: I knew of this before, but to&H9; speak truth,
This present grief had wiped it from my mind,
Go in&H5; with me and counsel every man,
The aptest way for&H4; safety and revenge,
Get posts and letters, and make friends with speed,
Never so&H51; few, and never yet more need.

div2.stage: Enter sir Iohn alone, with his page bearing his sword and buckler.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p: Sirrah, you giant, what says the doctor to&H4; my water?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p:
He said sir, the water itself was a good healthy water,
but for&H4; the party that&H61; owed it, he might have more diseases than
he knew for&H5;.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p:
Men of all sorts take a pride to&H9; gird at me: the brain
of this foolish compounded clay-man is not able to&H9; invent any
thing that&H61; intends to&H4; laughter, more than I invent, or is invented
on&H4; me, I am not only witty in&H4; myself, but the cause that&H3; wit is
in&H4; other men. I do here walk before thee, like&H4; a sow that&H61; hath
overwhelmed all her&H2; litter but one, if the prince put thee into my
service for&H4; any other reason than to&H9; set me off, why then I
have no&H2; judgment thou whoreson mandrake, thou art fitter to&H9;
be worn in&H4; my cap, than to&H9; wait at my heels I was never manned with an agot till now, but I will&H1; in-set you, neither in&H4; gold
nor silver, but in&H4; vile apparel, and send you back again to&H4;
your master for&H4; a jewel, the juvenal the prince your master,
whose chin is not yet fledge, I will&H1; sooner have a beard grow
in&H4; the palm of my hand, than he shall get one off his cheek, and
yet he will&H1; not stick to&H9; say his face is a face royal, God may finish it when he will&H1;, it is not a hair amiss yet, he may keep it
still at a face royal, for&H3; a barber shall never earn sixpence out
of it, and yet he will&H1; be crowing as if he had write man ever
since his father was a bachelor, he may keep his own grace,
but he is almost out of mine I can assure him: what said master
Dommelton about the satin for&H4; my short cloak and my
slops?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p:
He said sir, you should procure him better assurance
than Bardolfe, he would not take his band and yours, he liked
not the security.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p:
Let him be damned like&H4; the glutton, pray God his
tongue be hotter, a whoreson Achitophel! a rascal: yea forsooth
knave, to&H9; bear a gentle man in&H4; hand, and then stand upon&H4; security, the whoreson smoothy-pates do now wear nothing but
hie shoes and bunches of keys at their girdles, and if a man is
through with them in&H4; honest taking up&H5;, then they must stand
upon&H4; security, I had as live they would put ratsbane in&H4; my
mouth as offer to&H9; stop it with security, I looked he should have
sent me two and twenty yards of satin (as I am a true knight,)
and he sends me security: well he may sleep in&H4; security, for&H3; he
hath the horn of abundance, and the lightness of his wife
shines through it: where is Bardolf, and yet cannot he see though
he have his own lantern to&H9; light him.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: He is gone in&H4; Smithfield to&H9; buy your worship a horse.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p:
I bought him in&H4; Paules, and he will&H1; buy me a horse
in&H4; Smithfield, and I could get me but a wife in&H4; the stews, I
were manned, horsed, and wived.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p:
Sir, here comes the noble man that&H61; committed the prince
for&H4; striking him about Bardolfe.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: Wait close, I will&H1; not see him.

sp.speaker: Iustice
sp.p: What is he that&H61; goes there?

sp.speaker: seru.
sp.p: Falstaffe, if it please your lordship.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: He that&H61; was in&H4; question for&H4; the robbery?

sp.speaker: seru.
Iust.
sp.p: What to&H4; Yorke? call him back again.

sp.speaker: seru.
sp.p: Sir Iohn Falstaffe.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p: Boy, tell him I am deaf.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: You must speak louder, my master is deaf.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p:
I am sure he is to&H4; the hearing of anything good, go
pluck him by&H4; the elbow, I must speak with him.

sp.speaker: seru.
sp.p: Sir Iohn?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
What? a young knave and begging? is there not wars?
is there not employment? doth not the King lack subjects? do
not the rebels need soldiers, though it be a shame to&H9; be on&H4; any
side but one, it is worse shame to&H9; beg than to&H9; be on&H4; the worst
side, were it worse than the name of Rebellion can tell how to&H9;
make it.

sp.speaker: seru.
sp.p: You mistake me sir.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p:
Why sir, did I say you were an honest man, setting my
knighthood and my soldiership aside, I had lied in&H4; my throat
if I had said so.

sp.speaker: seru.
sp.p:
I pray you sir then set your knighthood, and your soldiership aside, and give me leave to&H9; tell you, you lie in&H4; your
throat, if you say I am any other than an honest man.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p:
I give thee leave to&H9; tell me, so&H3; I lay aside that&H62; which&H61;
grows to&H4; me, if thou gettest any leave of me, hang me, if thou
takest leave, thou wert better be hanged, you hunt counter, hence,
avaunt.

sp.speaker: seru.
sp.p: Sir, my Lord would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Sir Iohn Falstaffe, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
My good Lord, God give your lordship good time
of day, I am glad to&H9; see your lordship abroad, I heard say your
lordship was sick, I hope your lordship goes abroad by&H4; advice, your lordship, though not clean past your youth, have yet
some smack of an ague in&H4; you, some relish of the saltness of time
in&H4; you, and I most humbly beseech your lordship to&H9; have a reverend care of your health.

sp.speaker: Iustice
sp.p:
Sir Iohn, I sent for&H4; you before your expedition to&H4;
Shrewsbury.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p: If it please your lordship, I hear his majesty is returned with some discomfort from Wales.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p:
I talk not of his majesty, you would not come when I
sent for&H4; you.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
And I hear moreover, his highness is fallen into this
same whoreson apoplexy.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p:
Well, God mend him, I pray you let me speak with
you.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
This apoplexy as I take it? is a kind of lethargy, if it
please your lordship, a kind of sleeping in&H4; the blood, a whoreson
tingling.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: What tell you me of it, be it as it is.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
It hath it original from much grief, from study, and
perturbation of the brain, I have read the cause of his effects
in&H4; Galen, it is a kind of deafness.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p:
I think you are fallen into the disease, for&H3; you hear not
what I say to&H4; you.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
Very well my lord, very well, rather if it please you it is
the disease of not listening, the malady of not marking that&H3; I
am troubled withal.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p:
To&H9; punish you by&H4; the heels, would amend the attention of your ears, and I care not if I do become your
physician.

sp.speaker: Falst.
Iust.
sp.p:
I sent for&H4; you when there were matters against you for&H4;
your life to&H9; come speak with me.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
As I was then advised by&H4; my learned counsel in&H4; the
laws of this land service, I did not come.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Well, the truth is sir Iohn, you live in&H4; great infamy.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
He that&H61; buckles himself in&H4; my belt cannot live in&H4;
less.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Your means are very slender, and your waste is great.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
I would it were otherwise, I would my means were
greater and my waste slender.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: You have misled the youthful prince.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
The young prince hath misled me, I am the fellow with
the great belly, and he my dog.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p:
Well, I am loath to&H9; gall a new healed wound, your days
service at Shrewsbury, hath a little gilded over your nights
exploit on&H4; Gadshill, you may thank the unquiet time, for&H4; your
quiet overposting that&H62; action.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: My lord.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p:
But since all is well, keep it so&H52;, wake not a sleeping
wolf.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: To&H9; wake a wolf, is as bad as smell a fox.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: What you are as a candle, the better part, burnt out.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
A wassail candle my lord, all tallow, if I did say of wax,
my growth would approve the truth.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p:
There is not a white hair in&H4; your face, but should
have his effect of gravity.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: His effect of gravy, gravy, gravy.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p:
You follow the young prince up&H5; and down, like&H4; his
ill angel.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Not so&H52; my lord, your ill angel is light, but I hope he
that&H61; looks upon&H4; me will&H1; take me without weighing, and yet
in&H4; some respects I grant I cannot go. I cannot tell, virtue is of
so&H51; little regard in&H4; these costar-mongers times, that&H3; true valour
is turned Berod, Pregnancy is made a Tapster, and his quick wit
wasted in&H4; giving reckonings, all the other gifts appertinent
to&H4; man, as the malice of his age shapes the one not worth a
gooseberry, you that&H61; are old consider not the capacities of us&Htp; that&H61;
are young, you do measure the heat of our&Htp; livers with the bitterness of your galls, and we&Htp; that&H61; are in&H4; the vanguard of our&Htp;
youth, I must confess are wags too.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p:
Do you set down your name in&H4; the scroll of youth,
that&H61; are written down, old with all the characters of age? have
you not a moist eye, a dry hand, a yellow cheek, a white beard,
a decreasing leg, an increasing belly? is not your voice broken,
your wind short, your chin double, your wit single, and every part about you blasted with antiquity, and will&H1; you yet
call yourself young? fie, fie, fie, sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p:
My Lord, I was born about three of the clock in&H4;
the afternoon, with a white head, and something a round belly, for&H4; my voice, I have lost it with hallowing, and singing of
Anthems: to&H9; approve my youth further, I will&H1; not: the truth
is, I am only old in&H4; judgment and understanding: and he
that&H61; will&H1; caper with me for&H4; a thousand marks, let him lend me
the money, and have at him for&H4; the box of the year that&H61; the
Prince gave you, he gave it like&H4; a rude Prince, and you took
it like&H4; a sensible Lord: I have checked him for&H4; it, and the young
lion repents, marry not in&H4; ashes and sackcloth, but in&H4; new silk,
and old sack.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p: Well, God send the prince a better companion.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p:
God send the companion a better prince, I cannot
rid my hands of him.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p:
Well, the King hath severed you: I hear you are going with lord Iohn of Lancaster, against the Archbishop and
the Earl of Northumberland.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p:
Yea, I thank your pretty sweet wit for&H4; it: but look
you pray, all you that&H61; kiss my lady Peace at home, that&H3; our&Htp;
armies join not in&H4; a hot day, for&H3;, by&H4; the Lord, I take but two
shirts out with me, and I mean not to&H9; sweat extraordinarily:
if it be a hot day, and I brandish anything but a bottle. I would
I might never spit white again: there is not a dangerous action
can peep out his head, but I am thrust upon&H4; it. Well, I cannot
last ever, but it was always yet the trick of our&Htp; English nation,
if they have a good thing, to&H9; make it too common. If ye will&H1;
needs say I am an old man, you should give me rest: I would
to&H4; God my name were not so&H51; terrible to&H4; the enemy as it is, I
were better to&H9; be eaten to&H4; death with a rust, than to&H9; be scoured
to&H4; nothing with perpetual motion.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p: Well, be honest, be honest, and God bless your expedition.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p: Will&H1; your lordship lend me a thousand pound to&H9; furnish me forth?

sp.speaker: Lord
Iohn
sp.p:
If I do, fillip me with a three man beetle: A man can
no&H2; more separate age and covetousness, than he can part young
limbs and lechery, but the gout galls the one, and the pox
pinches the other, and so&H3; both the degrees prevent my curses, boy.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p: What money is in&H4; my purse?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Seven groats and two pence.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p:
I can get no&H2; remedy against this consumption of the
purse, borrowing only lingers and lingers it out, but the disease is incurable: Go bear this letter to&H4; my lord of Lancaster,
this to&H4; the Prince, this to&H4; the Earl of Westmerland, and this to&H4;
old mistress Vrsula, whom I have weekly sworn to&H9; marry
since I perceived the first white hair of my chin: about it, you
know where to&H9; find me: a pox of this gout, or a gout of this
pox, for&H3; the one or the other plays the rogue with my great
toe. It is no&H2; matter if I do halt, I have the wars for&H4; my
colour, and my pension shall seem the more reasonable: a good
wit will&H1; make use of anything; I will&H1; turn diseases to&H4; commodity.

div2.stage: Enter th'Archbishop, Thomas Mowbray (Earle Marshall) the Lord Hastings, Fauconbridge, and Bardolfe.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Thus have you heard our&Htp; cause, and known our&Htp; means,
And my most noble friends, I pray you all
Speak plainly your opinions of our&Htp; hopes,
And first Lord Marshall, what say you to&H4; it?

sp.speaker: Marsh.
sp.l: I well allow the occasion of our&Htp; arms,
But gladly would be better satisfied,
How in&H4; our&Htp; means we&Htp; should advance ourselves,
To&H9; look with forehead, bold, and big enough,
Upon&H4; the power and puissance of the King.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: Our&Htp; present musters grow upon&H4; the file,
To&H4; five and twenty thousand men of choice,
And our&Htp; supplies live largely in&H4; the hope
Of great Northumberland, whose bosom burns
With an incensed fire of injuries.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: The question then Lord Hastings standeth thus,
Whether our&Htp; present five and twenty thousand,
May hold up&H5; head without Northumberland.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: With him we&Htp; may.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: Yea marry, there is the point,
But if without him we&Htp; be thought too feeble,
My judgment is we&Htp; should not step too far.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: It is very true lord Bardolfe, for&H3; indeed
It was young Hot-spurs cause at Shrewsbury.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: It was my Lord, who&H61; lined himself with hope,
Eating the air, and promise of supply,
Flattering himself in&H4; project of a power,
Much smaller than the smallest of his thoughts,
And so&H3; with great imagination,
Proper to&H4; mad-men, led his powers to&H4; death,
And winking, leapt into destruction.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: But by&H4; your leave it never yet did hurt,
To&H9; lay down likelihoods and forms of hope.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: We&Htp; fortify in&H4; paper, and in&H4; figures,
Using the names of men in&H4; steed of men,
Like&H4; one that&H61; draws the model of an house,
Beyond his power to&H9; build it, who&H61; (half thorough)
Gives over, and leaves his part-created cost,
A naked subject to&H4; the weeping clouds,
And waste for&H4; churlish winters tyranny.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: Grant that&H3; our&Htp; hopes (yet likely of fair birth)
Should be still-born, and that&H3; we&Htp; now possessed
The utmost man of expectation,
I think we&Htp; are so&H52;, body strong enough,
Even as we&Htp; are to&H9; equal with the King.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: What, is the King but five and twenty thousand?

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: To&H4; us&Htp; no&H2; more, nay not so&H51; much, Lord Bardolfe,
For&H3; his divisions, as the times do brawl,
And in&H4; three heads, one power against the French,
And one against Glendower perforce a third
Must take up&H5; us&Htp;, so&H3; is the infirm King
In&H4; three divided, and his coffers sound
With hollow poverty and emptiness.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: That&H3; he should draw his several strengths together,
And come against us&Htp; in&H4; full puissance,
Need not to&H9; be dreaded.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: If he should do so&H52;, French and Welsh he leaves his
back unarmed, they baying him at the heels, never fear that&H62;.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Who&H62; is it like&H5; should lead his forces hither?

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: The Duke of Lancaster and Westmerland:
Against the Welsh, himself and Harry Monmouth:
But who&H61; is substituted against the French
I have no&H2; certain notice.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: Shall we&Htp; go draw our&Htp; numbers, and set on&H5;?

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: We&Htp; are Times subjects, and Time bids be gone.

div2.stage: Enter Hostesse of the Tauerne, and an Officer or two.

sp.speaker: Hostesse
sp.p: Master Phang, have you entered the action?

sp.speaker: Phang
sp.p: It is entered.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Where is your yeoman? is it a lusty yeoman? will&H1; he stand
to&H4; it?

sp.speaker: Phang
sp.p: Sirrah, where is Snare?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: O Lord I, good master Snare.

sp.speaker: Snare
sp.p: Here, here.

sp.speaker: Phang
sp.p: Snare, we&Htp; must arrest sir Iohn Falstaffe.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Yea good master Snare, I have entered him and all.

sp.speaker: Snare
sp.p:
It may chance cost some of us&Htp; our&Htp; lives, for&H3; he will&H1;
stab.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Alas the day, take heed of him, he stabbed me in&H4; mine
own house, most beastly in&H4; good faith, he cares not what mischief he does, if his weapon be out, he will&H1; foin like&H4; any devil, he will&H1; spare neither man, woman, nor child.

sp.speaker: Phang
sp.p: If I can close with him, I care not for&H4; his thrust.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: No&H7; nor I neither, I will&H1; be at your elbow.

sp.speaker: Phang
sp.p:
If I but fist him once, and he come but within my
view.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
I am undone by&H4; his going, I warrant you, he is an infinitive thing upon&H4; my score, good master Phang hold him
sure, good master Snare let him not scape, he comes continually
to&H4; Pie corner (saving your manhoods) to&H9; buy a saddle, and he
is indicted to&H4; dinner to&H4; the Lubbers head in&H4; Lumbert street to&H4;
master Smooths the silk man, I pray you since my exion is entered, and my case so&H51; openly known to&H4; the world, let him be
brought in&H5; to&H4; his answer, a hundred mark is a long one, for&H4; a
poor lone woman to&H9; bear, and I have borne, and borne, and
borne, and have been fubbed off, and fubbed off, and fubbed off, from
this day to&H4; that&H62; day, that&H3; it is a shame to&H9; be thought on&H5;, there is
no&H2; honesty in&H4; such dealing, unless a woman should be made
an ass, and a beast, to&H9; bear every knaves wrong: yonder he
comes, and that&H62; arrant malmsey-nose knave Bardolfe with him,
do your offices do your offices master Phang, and master Snare,
do me, do me, do me your offices.

div2.stage: Enter sir Iohn, and Bardolfe, and the boy.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: How now, whose mare is dead? what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Phang
sp.p: I arrest you at the suit of mistress Quickly.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Away varlets, draw Bardolfe, cut me off the villains
head, throw the quean in&H4; the channel.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Throw me in&H4; the channel? I will&H1; throw thee in&H4; the channel, wilt thou, wilt thou, thou bastardly rogue, murder murder,
a thou honeysuckle villain, wilt thou kill Gods officers and the
Kings? a thou honeyseed rogue, thou art a honeyseed, a man queller, and a woman queller.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Keep them off Bardolfe.

sp.speaker: Offic.
sp.p: A rescue, a rescue.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Good people bring a rescue or two, thou wot, wot
thou, thou wot, wot ta, do do thou rogue, do thou hempseed.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p:
Away you scullion, you rampallian, you fustilarian, I will&H1;
tickle your catastrophe.

div2.stage: Enter Lord chiefe iustice and his men.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: What is the matter? keep the peace here, ho.

sp.speaker: Hostesse
sp.p:
Good my lord be good to&H4; me, I beseech you stand
to&H4; me.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: How now sir Iohn, what are you brawling here?
Doth this become your place, your time, and business?
You should have been well on&H4; your way to&H4; Yorke:
Stand from him fellow, wherefore hangest thou upon&H4; him.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
O my most worshipful Lord, if it please your grace
I am a poor widow of Eastcheape, and he is arrested at my
suit.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: For&H4; what sum?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
It is more than for&H4; some my Lord, it is for&H4; all I have, he
hath eaten me out of house and home, he hath put all my substance into that&H62; fat belly of his, but I will&H1; have some of it out again, or I will&H1; ride thee a-nights like&H4; the mare.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: I think I am as like&H5; to&H9; ride the mare if I have any vantage of ground to&H9; get up&H5;.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p:
How comes this sir Iohn? what man of good temper
would endure this tempest of exclamation; are you not ashamed to&H9; enforce a poor widow, to&H4; so&H51; rough a course to&H9; come
by&H4; her own.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: What is the gross sum that&H61; I owe thee?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Marry if thou wert an honest man, thyself and the
money too: thou didst swear to&H4; me upon&H4; a parcel guilt goblet,
sitting in&H4; my dolphin chamber, at the round table by&H4; a sea cole
fire, upon&H4; wednesday in&H4; Wheeson week, when the prince
broke thy head, for&H4; liking his father to&H4; a singing man of Winsor, thou didst swear to&H4; me then, as I was washing thy wound,
to&H9; marry me, and make me my lady thy wife, canst thou deny
it, did not goodwife Keech the butchers wife come in&H5; then and
call me gossip Quickly, coming in&H5; to&H9; borrow a mess of vinegar, telling us&Htp; she had a good dish of prawns, whereby thou
didst desire to&H9; eat some, whereby I told thee they were ill
for&H4; a green wound, and didst thou not, when she was gone
down stairs, desire me, to&H9; be no&H2; more so&H51; familiarity, with such
poor people, saying that&H3; ere long they should call me madam,
and didst thou not kiss me, and bid me fetch thee thirty shillings, I put thee now to&H4; thy book oath, deny it if thou canst.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
My lord this is a poor mad soul, and she says up&H4;
and down the town, that&H3; her&H2; eldest son is like&H4; you, she
hath been in&H4; good case, and the truth is poverty hath distracted
her&H6;, but for&H4; these foolish officers, I beseech you I may have redress against them.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p:
Sir Iohn, sir Iohn, I am well acquainted with your manner
of wrenching the true cause, the false way: it is not a confident
brow, nor the throng of words that&H61; come with such more than
impudent sauciness from you, can thrust me from a level consideration: you have as it appears to&H4; me practised upon&H4; the
easy yielding spirit of this woman, and made her&H6; serve your
uses both in&H4; purse and in&H4; person.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Yea in&H4; truth my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p:
Pray thee peace, pay her&H6; the debt you owe her&H6;, and unhap the villainy you have done with her&H6;, the one you may do
with sterling money, and the other with currant repentance.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
My Lord I will&H1; not undergo this snipe without reply, you call honourable boldness impudent sauciness, if a man
will&H1; make curtsy and say nothing, he is virtuous, no&H7; my Lord
my humble duty remembered, I will&H1; not be your suitor, I say
to&H4; you I do desire deliverance from these officers, being upon&H4;
hasty employment in&H4; the Kings affairs.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p: You speak as having power to&H9; do wrong, but answer in&H4; the effect of your reputation, and satisfy the poor woman.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Come hither hostess.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Now master Gower, what news.

sp.speaker: Gower
sp.l: The King my Lord, and Harry prince of Wales,
Are near at hand, the rest the paper tells.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: As I am a gentleman!

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Faith you said so&H52; before.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: As I am a gentleman, come, no&H2; more words of it.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
By&H4; this heavenly ground I tread on&H5;, I must be fain to&H9;
pawn both my plate, and the tapestry of my dining chambers -

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Glasses glasses is the only drinking, and for&H4; thy walls
a pretty sleight drollery, or the story of the prodigal, or the
Jarman hunting in&H4; waterwork, is worth a thousand of these
bed-hangers, and these fly bitten tapestry, let it be ten pounds if thou
canst: come, and it were not for&H4; thy humours, there is not a better
wench in&H4; England, go wash thy face and draw the action,
come thou must not be in&H4; this humour with me, dost not know
me, come, come, I know thou wast set on&H5; to&H4; this.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Pray thee sir Iohn let it be but twenty nobles, i'faith
I am loath to&H9; pawn my plate so&H52; God save me law.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Let it alone, I will&H1; make other shift, you will&H1; be a fool still.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Well, you shall have it, though I pawn my gown,
I hope you will&H1; come to&H4; supper, you will&H1; pay me all together.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
will&H1; I live? go with her&H6;, with her&H6;, hook on&H5;, hook
on&H5;.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Will&H1; you have Doll Tere-sheet meet you at supper.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: No&H2; more words, let us&Htp; have her&H6;.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p: I have heard better news.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: What is the news my lord?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p: Where lay the King tonight?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: At Billingsgate my Lord.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: I hope my Lord all is well, what is the news my lord?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Come all his forces back?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: No&H7;, fifteen hundred foot, five hundred horse
Are marched up&H5; to&H4; my lord of Lancaster,
Against Northumberland, and the Archbishop.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.l: Comes the King back from Wales, my noble lord?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: You shall have letters of me presently,
Come, go along with me, good master Gower.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: My lord.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Falstaffe
sp.p:
Master Gower, shall I entreat you with me to&H4;
dinner?

sp.speaker: Gower
sp.p:
I must wait upon&H4; my good lord here, I thank you
good sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Lord
Falstaffe
sp.p: Will&H1; you sup with me master Gower?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p:
What foolish master taught you these manners, sir
Iohn?

sp.speaker: Falstaffe
sp.p:
Master Gower, if they become me not, he was a
fool that&H61; taught them me: this is the right fencing grace, my
Lord, tap for&H4; tap, and so&H3; part fair.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.p: Now the Lord lighten thee, thou art a great fool.

div2.stage: Enter the Prince, Poynes, sir Iohn Russel, with other.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Before God, I am exceeding weary.

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p:
Is it come to&H4; that&H62;? I had thought weariness durst not
have attached one of so&H51; hie blood.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Faith it does me, though it discolours the complexion of my greatness to&H4; acknowledge it: doth it not show vildly
in&H4; me, to&H9; desire small beer?

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p:
Why a Prince should not be so&H51; loosely studied, as
to&H9; remember so&H51; weak a composition.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Belike then my appetite was not princely got, for&H3;
by&H4; my troth, I do now remember the poor creature small beer.
But indeed these humble considerations make me out of love
with my greatness. What a disgrace is it to&H4; me to&H9; remember
thy name? or to&H9; know thy face tomorrow? or to&H9; take note how
many pair of silk stockings thou hast with these, and those
that&H61; were thy peach coloured once, or to&H9; bear the inventory of
thy shirts, as one for&H4; superfluity, and another for&H4; use. But that&H3;
the Tennis court keeper knows better than I, for&H3; it is a low ebb
of linen with thee when thou keepest not racket there, as thou
hast not done a great while, because the rest of the low Countries have eat up&H5; thy holland: and God knows whether those
that&H61; ball out the ruins of thy linen shall inherit his kingdom:
but the Midwives say, the children are not in&H4; the fault whereupon the world increases, and kindred's are mightily strengthened.

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p:
How ill it follows, after you have laboured so&H51; hard,
you should talk so&H51; idly! tell me how many good young princes would do so&H52;, their fathers being so&H51; sick, as yours at this
time is.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Shall I tell thee one thing Poynes?

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: Yes faith, and let it be an excellent good thing.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
It shall serve among wits of no&H2; higher breeding
than thine.

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p:
Go to&H5;, I stand the push of your one thing that&H61; you
will&H1; tell.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Marry I tell thee it is not meet that&H3; I should be sad
now my father is sick, albeit I could tell to&H4; thee, as to&H4; one it
pleases me for&H4; fault of a better to&H9; call my friend, I could be sad,
and sad indeed too.

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: Very hardly, upon&H4; such a subject.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
By&H4; this hand, thou thinkest me as far in&H4; the devils
book, as thou and Falstaffe, for&H3; obduracy and persistence,
let the end try the man, but I tell thee, my heart bleeds inwardly that&H3; my father is so&H51; sick, and keeping such vile company as
thou art, hath in&H4; reason taken from me all ostentation of sorrow.

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: The reason.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: What wouldst thou think of me if I should weep?

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: I would think thee a most princely hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
It would be every man's thought, and thou art
a blessed fellow, to&H9; think as every man thinks, never a man's
thought in&H4; the world, keeps the rode way better than thine,
every man would think me an hypocrite indeed, and what
accites your most worshipful thought to&H9; think so&H52;?

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p:
Why because you have been so&H51; lewd and so&H51; much
ingrafted to&H4; Falstaffe.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: And to&H4; thee.

sp.speaker: Poyne
sp.p:
By&H4; this light I am well spoke on&H5;, I can hear it with
mine own ears, the worst that&H61; they can say of me is that&H3; I am
a second brother, and that&H3; I am a proper fellow of my hands,
and those two things I confess I cannot help: by&H4; the mass
here comes Bardolfe.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
And the boy that&H61; I gave Falstaffe, he had him from
me Christian, and look if the fat villain have not transformed
him Ape.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: God save your grace.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: And yours most noble Bardolfe.

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p:
Come you virtuous ass, you bashful fool, must
you be blushing, wherefore blush you now? what a maidenly
man at arms are you become? is it such a matter to get a pottle-pots
maidenhead?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p:
He calls me enough my Lord, through a red lattice, and I
could discern no&H2; part of his face from the window, at last I
spied his eyes, and methought he had made two holes in&H4; the ale
wives petticoat and so&H3; peeped through.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Has not the boy profited?

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: Away you whoreson upright rabble, away.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Away you rascally Altheas dream, away.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Instruct us&Htp; boy, what dream boy?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p:
Marry my lord, Althear dreamt she was delivered of
a firebrand, and therefore I call him her dream.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: A crowns worth of good interpretation there it is boy.

sp.speaker: Poines
sp.p:
O that&H3; this blossom could be kept from cankers!
well, there is sixpence to&H9; preserve thee.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: If you do not make him hanged among you, the gallows shall have wrong.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: And how doth thy master Bardolfe?

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p:
Well my Lord, he heard of your graces coming to
town, there is a letter for&H4; you.

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: Delivered with good respect, and how doth the martlemasse your master?

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: In&H4; bodily health sir.

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p:
Marry the immortal part needs a physician, but that&H62;
moves not him, though that&H62; be sick, it dies not.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
I do allow this Wen to&H9; be as familiar with me, as my
dog, and he holds his place, for&H3; look you how he writes.

sp.speaker: Poynes
Prince
sp.p:
Nay they will&H1; be kin to&H4; us&Hrp;, or they will fetch it from
Iaphet, but the letter,
Sir Iohn Falstaffe knight, to&H4; the son of
the king, nearest his father, Harry prince of Wales, greeting.

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: Why this is a certificate.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Peace.
I will imitate the honourable Romans in&H4; brevity.

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: He sure means brevity in&H4; breath, short winded,

I commend me to&H4; thee, I commend thee, and, I leave
thee, be not too familiar with Poynes, for&H3; he misuses thy favours so&H51; much, that&H3; he swears thou art to&H9; marry his sister Nel,
repent at idle times as thou mayest, and so&H3; farewell.
Thine by yea, and no&H7;, which&H61; is as much as to&H9; say, as
thou usest him, Iacke Falstaffe with my family,
Iohn with my brothers and sisters, and sir Iohn
with all Europe.

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p:
My Lord, I will&H1; steep this letter in&H4; sack and make him
eat it.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
That&H62; is to&H9; make him eat twenty of his words, but do
you use me, thus Ned? must I marry your sister?

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p:
God send the wench no&H2; worse fortune, but I never
said so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Well, thus we play the fools with the time, and the
spirits of the wise sit in&H4; the clouds and mock us&Htp;, is your master here in&H4; London?

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: Yea my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Where sups he? doth the old boar feed in&H4; the old
Frank?

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: At the old place, my lord, in&H4; Eastcheape.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: What company?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Ephesians, my lord, of the old church.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Sup any women with him?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p:
None my lord, but old mistress Quickly, and mistress Dol
Tere-sheet.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: What Pagan may that&H62; be?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p:
A proper gentlewoman sir, and a kinswoman of my
masters.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Even such kin as the parish Heifers are to&H4; the
town bull, shall we&Htp; steal upon&H4; them Ned at supper?

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: I am your shadow my Lord, I will&H1; follow you.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Sirrah, you boy and Bardolfe, no&H2; word to&H4; your master that&H3; I am yet come to&H4; town; there is for&H4; your silence.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I have no&H2; tongue sir.

sp.speaker: >Boy
sp.p: And for&H4; mine sir, I will&H1; govern it.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Fare you well: go, this Doll Tere-sheete should be
some rode.

sp.speaker: Poyns
sp.p: I warrant you, as common as the way between S. Albons and London.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
How might we&Htp; see Falstaffe bestow himself tonight
in&H4; his true colours, and not ourselves be seen?

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p:
Put on&H5; two leathern jerkins and aprons, and wait
upon&H4; him at his table as drawers.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
From a god to&H4; a bull, a heavy dissension, it was Ioues
case, from a prince to&H4; a prentice, a low transformation, that&H61; shall
be mine, for&H3; in&H4; every thing the purpose must weigh with the
folly, follow me Ned.

div2.stage: Enter Northumberland his wife, and the wife to Harry Percie.

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: I pray thee loving wife and gentle daughter,
Give even way unto my rough affairs,
Put not you on&H5; the visage of the times,
And be like&H4; them to&H4; Percy troublesome.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: I have given over, I will&H1; speak no&H2; more,
Do what you will&H1;, your wisdom be your guide.

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: Alas sweet wife, my honour is at pawn,
And but my going, nothing can redeem it.

sp.speaker: Kate
sp.l: O yet for&H4; Gods sake, go not to&H4; these wars,
The time was father, that&H3; you broke your word,
When you were more endear to&H4; it than now,
When your own Percie, when my hearts dear Harry,
Threw many a Northward look, to&H9; see his father
Bring up&H5; his powers, but he did long in&H4; vain.
Who&H62; then persuaded you to&H9; stay at home?
There were two honours lost, yours, and your sons,
For&H4; yours, the God of heaven brighten it,
For&H4; his, it stuck upon&H4; him as the sun
In the grey vault of heaven, and by his light
Did all the Chivalry of England move
To&H9; do brave acts, he was indeed the glass
Wherein the noble youth did dress themselves.

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: Beshrew your heart,
Fair daughter, you do draw my spirits from me,
With new lamenting ancient oversights,
But I must go and meet with danger there,
Or it will&H1; seek me in&H4; an other place,
And find me worse provided.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: O fly to&H4; Scotland,
Till that&H3; the nobles and the armed commons,
Have of their puissance made a little taste.

sp.speaker: Kate
sp.l: If they get ground and vantage of the King,
Then join you with them like&H4; a rib of steel,
To&H9; make strength stronger: but for&H4; all our&Htp; loves,
First let them try themselves, so&H52; did your son,
He was so&H52; suffered, so&H52; came I a widow,
And never shall have length of life enough,
To&H9; rain upon&H4; remembrance with mine eyes,
That&H3; it may grow and sprout as high as heaven,
For&H4; recordation to&H4; my noble husband.

sp.speaker: North.
sp.l: Come, come, go in&H4; with me, it is with my mind,
As with the tide, swelled up&H5; unto his height,
That&H61; makes a still stand, running neither way,
Fain would I go to&H9; meet the Archbishop,
But many thousand reasons hold me back,
I will&H1; resolve for&H4; Scotland, there am I,
Till time and vantage crave my company.

sp.speaker: Francis
sp.p:
What the devil hast thou brought there apple
Iohns? thou knowest sir Iohn cannot endure an apple Iohn.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p:
Mass thou sayst true, the prince once set a dish of apple Iohns before him, and told him there were five more sir
Iohns, and putting off his hat, said, I will&H1; now take my leave of
these six dry, round, old, withered Knights, it angered him to&H4;
the heart, but he hath forgot that&H62;.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Why then cover and set them down, and see if
thou canst find out Sneakes Noise, mistress Tere-sheet would
fain hear some music.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p:
Dispatch, the room where they supped is too hot, they will&H1;
come in&H5; straight.

sp.speaker: Francis
sp.p:
Sirrah, here will&H1; be the prince and master Poynes anon, and they will&H1; put on&H5; two of our&Htp; jerkins and aprons, and sir
Iohn must not know of it, Bardolfe hath brought word.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p:
By&H4; the mass here will&H1; be old vtis, it will&H1; be an excellent
stratagem.

sp.speaker: Francis
sp.p: I will&H1; see if I can find out Sneake.

div2.stage: Enter mistris Quickly, and Doll Tere-sheet.

sp.speaker: Quickly
sp.p:
I'faith sweet heart, methinks now you are in&H4; an
excellent good temporality. Your pulse beats as extraordinarily as heart would desire, and your colour I warrant you
is as red as any rose, in&H4; good truth law: but i'faith you have
drunk too much canaries, and that&H62; is a marvelous searching
wine, and it perfumes the blood ere one can say, what is this,
how do you now?

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p: Better than I was: hem.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Why that&H62; is well said, a good heart is worth gold: lo
here comes sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p:
When Arthur first in&H4; court,
empty the jordan
and
was a worthy King
: how now mistress Doll?

sp.speaker: host.
sp.p: Sick of a calm, yea good faith.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
So&H52; is all her&H2; sect, if they be once in&H4; a calm they are
sick.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p:
A pox damn you, you muddy rascal, is that&H62; all the
comfort you give me?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: You make fat rascals mistress Dol.

sp.speaker: Tere.
sp.p:
I make them? gluttony, and diseases make, I make
them not.

sp.speaker: Falst.
Doll
sp.p: Yea joy, our&Htp; chains and our&Htp; jewels.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
Your brooches, pearls, and ouches for&H3; to&H9; serve bravely,
is to&H9; come halting off, you know to&H9; come off the breach, with
his pike bent bravely, and to&H4; surgery bravely, to&H9; venture upon&H4;
the charged chambers bravely.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: Hang yourself, you muddy Conger, hang yourself.

sp.speaker: host
sp.p:
By&H4; my troth this is the old fashion, you two never meet
but you fall to&H4; some discord, you are both i'good truth as rheumatic
as two dry toasts, you cannot one bear with another's
confirmities, what the good year one must bear, and that&H62; must be
you, you are the weaker vessel, as they say, the emptier vessel.

sp.speaker: Dorothy
sp.p:
Can a weak empty vessel bear such a huge full
hogshead? there is a whole merchants venture of Bordeaux stuff
in&H4; him, you have not seen a hulk better stuffed in&H4; the hold.
Come, I will&H1; be friends with thee iacke, thou art going to&H4; the
wars, and whether I shall ever see thee again or no&H5; there is nobody
cares.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p:
Sir, Ancient pistol is below, and would speak with
you.

sp.speaker: Dol
sp.p:
Hang him swaggering rascal, let him not come hither
it is the foul-mouthedest rogue in&H4; England.

sp.speaker: host.
sp.p:
If he swagger, let him not come here, no&H7; by&H4; my faith I
must live among my neighbours, I will&H1; no&H2; swaggerers, I am in&H4;
good name, and fame with the very best: shut the door, there
comes no&H2; swaggerers here, I have not lived all this while to&H9; have
swaggering now, shut the door I pray you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Dost thou hear hostess?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Pray ye pacify yourself sir Iohn, there comes no&H2;
swaggerers here.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Dost thou hear? it is mine Ancient.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p:
Tilly fally, sir Iohn, never tell me: and your ancient swaggerer comes not in&H4; my doors: I was before master Tisicke
the deputy the other day, and (as he said to&H4; me) it was no&H2; longer ago
than wednesday last, In&H4; good faith, neighbour Quickely, says he,
master Dumb our&Htp; minister was by&H5; then, neighbour Quickly
(says he) receive those that&H61; are civil, for&H3; (said he) you are in&H4; an
ill name: now he said so&H52;, I can tell whereupon. For&H3; (says he)
you are an honest woman, and well thought on&H5;, therefore take
heed what guests you receive, receive (says he) no&H2; swaggering companions: there comes none here: you would bless
you to&H9; hear what he said: no&H7;, I will&H1; no&H2; swaggerers.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
He is no&H2; swaggerer hostess, a tame cheater i'faith, you
may stroke him as gently as a puppy grey-hound, he will&H1; not
swagger with a Barbary hen, if her feathers turn back in any
show of resistance, call him up&H5; Drawer.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Cheater call you him? I will&H1; bar no&H2; honest man my
house, nor no&H2; cheater, but I do not love swaggering by&H4; my troth,
I am the worse when one says swagger: feele masters, how I
shake, look you, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Teresh.
sp.p: So&H52; you do hostess.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Do I? yea in&H4; very truth do I, and it were an aspen
leaf, I cannot abide swaggerers.

div2.stage: Enter antient Pistol, and Bardolfes boy.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.p: God save you sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Welcome ancient Pistoll, here Pistoll, I charge you
with a cup of sack, do you discharge upon&H4; mine hostess.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: I will&H1; discharge upon&H4; her&H6; sir Iohn, with two bullets.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
she is pistol proof: sir, you shall not hardly offend
her&H6;.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Come, I will&H1; drink no&H2; proofs, nor no&H2; bullets, I will&H1; drink
no&H2; more than will&H1; do me good, for&H4; no&H2; man's pleasure, I.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: Then, to&H4; you mistress Dorothy, I will&H1; charge you.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p:
Charge me? I scorn you, scurvy companion: what
you poor base rascally cheating lack-linen mate? away you
mouldy rogue, away, I am meat for&H4; your master.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: I know you mistress Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p:
Away you cutpurse rascal, you filthy bung, away,
by&H4; this wine I will&H1; thrust my knife in&H4; your mouldy chaps, and
you play the saucy cuttle with me. Away you bottle ale rascal, you basket hilt stale juggler, you. Since when, I pray
you sir: Gods light, with two points on&H4; your shoulder? much.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p:
God let me not live, but I will&H1; murther your ruff for&H4;
this.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p:
No&H2; more Pistol, I would not have you go off here,
discharge yourself of our&Htp; company, Pistoll.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: No&H7;, good captain Pistoll, not here, sweet captain.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p:
Captain, thou abominable damned cheater, art thou
not ashamed to&H9; be called Captain? and Captains were of my
mind, they would truncheon you out, for&H4; taking their names
upon&H4; you, before you have earned them: you a captain? you
slave, for&H4; what? for&H4; tearing a poor whores ruff in&H4; a bawdy
house: he a captain! hang him rogue, he lives upon&H4; mouldy
stewed prunes, and dried cakes: a captain? Gods light these villains will&H1; make the word as odious as the word occupy, which&H61;
was an excellent good word before it was ill sorted, therefore
captains had need look to&H4; it.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: Pray thee go down good Ancient.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Hark thee hither mistress Dol.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p:
Not I, I tell thee what corporal Bardolfe, I could
tear her&H6;, I will&H1; be revenged of her&H6;.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Pray thee go down.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: I will&H1; see her&H6; damned first, to&H4; Plutoes damned lake by&H4; this
hand to&H4; the infernal deep, with erebus and tortures vile also: hold
hook and line, say I: down, down dogs, down faters have
we&Htp; not Hired here?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Good captain Peesell be quiet, it is very late i'faith, I
beseek you now aggravate your choler.

sp.speaker: Pist
sp.l: These be good humours indeed, shall pack-horses, and
hollow pampered jades of Asia which&H61; cannot go but thirty
mile a day, compare with Cæsars and with Cannibals, and trojan Greeks? nay rather damn them with King Cerberus, and
let the Welkin roar, shall we&Htp; fall foul for&H4; toys?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: By&H4; my troth captain, these are very bitter words.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p:
Be gone good Ancient, this will&H1; grow to&H4; a brawl
anon.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Men like&H4; dogs give crowns like&H4; pins, have we&Htp; not
Hired here?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
A my word Captain, there is none such here, what
the good year do you think I would deny her&H6;? for&H4; Gods sake
be quiet.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Then feed and be fat, my fair Calipolis, come gives
some sack, si fortune me torment sperato me contento, fear we&Htp;
broad sides? no&H7;, let the fiend give fire, give me some sack, and
sweet heart, lie thou there, come we&Htp; to&H4; full points here? and are and
cæteraes, nothings?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Pistol, I would be quiet.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p:
Sweet Knight, I kiss thy neaffe, what, we&Htp; have seen
the seven stars.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p:
For&H4; Gods sake thrust him down stairs, I cannot endure
such a fustian rascal.

sp.speaker: Pist
sp.p:
Thrust him down stairs, know we&Htp; not Galloway
nags?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Quiet him down Bardolfe like&H4; a shove groat shilling, nay, if he do nothing but speak nothing, he shall be nothing here.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: Come, get you down stairs.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: What shall we&Htp; have incision? shall we&Htp; imbrue? then
death rock me asleep, abridge my doleful days: why then
let grievous ghastly gaping wounds untwined the sisters three,
come Atropose I say.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Here is goodly stuff toward.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Give me my rapier, boy.

sp.speaker: Dol
sp.p: I pray thee Iacke, I pray thee do not draw.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Get you down stairs.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Here is a goodly tumult, I will&H1; forswear keeping house afore I will&H1; be in&H4; these tirrits and frights, so&H3;, murder I warrant now,
alas, alas, put up&H5; your naked weapons, put up&H5; your naked weapons.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: I pray thee Iack be quiet, the rascal is gone, ah you whoreson little valiant villain you.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Are you not hurt in&H4; the groin? methought he made a
shrewd thrust at your belly.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Have you turned him out of doors?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
Yea sir, the rascal is drunk, you have hurt him sir in&H4; the
shoulder.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: A rascal to&H9; brave me?

sp.speaker: Dol
sp.p:
A you sweet little rogue you, alas poor ape how thou
sweatest, come let me wipe thy face, come on&H5; you whoreson
chops: a rogue, i'faith I love thee, thou art as valorous as Hector of Troy, worth five of Agamemnon, and ten times better
than the nine Worthies, a villain!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Ah rascally slave! I will toss the rogue in&H4; a blanket.

sp.speaker: Dol
sp.p: Do and thou darest for&H4; thy heart, if thou dost, I will&H1; canvas thee between a pair of sheets.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: The music is come sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Let them play, play sirs, sit on&H4; my knee Doll, a rascal
bragging slave! the rogue fled from me like&H4; quicksilver.

sp.speaker: Dol
sp.p:
I'faith and thou followedest him like&H4; a church, thou
whoreson little tydee Bartholemew boar-pig, when wilt thou
leave fighting a-days and foining a-nights, and begin to&H9; patch
up&H5; thine old body for&H4; heaven.

sp.speaker: Fal
sp.p:
Peace good Doll, do not speak like&H4; a deaths head, do
not bid me remember mine end.

sp.speaker: Dol
sp.p: Sirrah, what humour is the prince of?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
A good shallow young fellow, he would have made a
good pantler, he would have chipped bread well.

sp.speaker: Dol
sp.p: They say Poines has a good wit.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
He a good wit? hang him baboon, his wit is as thick
as Tewksbury mustard, there is no&H2; more conceit in him than is
in&H4; a mallet.

sp.speaker: Dol
sp.p: Why does the prince love him so&H52; then?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Because their legs are both of a bigness, and he plays
at quoits well, and eats conger and fennel, and drinks off
candles ends for&H4; flap dragons, and rides the wild mare
with the boys, and jumps upon&H4; joint-stools, and swears
with a good grace, and wears his boots very smooth like&H5;
unto the sign of the Leg, and breeds no&H2; bate with telling of discreet stories, and such other gambol faculties he has
that&H61; show a weak mind, and an able body for&H4; the which the
prince admits him: for&H3; the prince himself is such another, the
weight of a hair will&H1; turn scales between their haber de poiz.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Would not this nave of a wheel have his ears cut
off?

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: Let us&Htp; beat him before his whore.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Look where the withered elder hath not his pole
clawed like&H4; a parrot.

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p:
Is it not strange that&H3; desire should so&H51; many years
out live performance.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Kiss me Doll.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Saturne and Venus this year in&H4; conjunction? what
says the Almanac to&H4; that&H62;?

sp.speaker: Poyns
sp.p:
And look whether the fiery Trigon his man be not
lisping to&H4; his master, old tables, his note book, his counsel keeper?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Thou dost give me flattering busses.

sp.speaker: Dol
sp.p: By&H4; my troth I kiss thee with a most constant heart.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: I am old, I am old.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p:
I love thee better than I love, ere a scurvy young boy of
them all.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
What stuff wilt have a kirtle of? I shall receive money
a thursday, shalt have a cap tomorrow: a merry song, come it
grows late, we&Htp; will&H1; to&H4; bed, thou wilt forget me when I am gone.

sp.speaker: Dol
sp.p:
By&H4; my troth thou wilt set me a-weeping if thou sayst so&H62;,
prove that&H3; ever I dress myself handsome till thy return, well
hearken at the end.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Some sack Francis.

sp.speaker: Prince, Poynes
sp.p: Anon anon sir.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Ha? a bastard son of the Kings? and art not thou
Poynes his brother?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Why thou globe of sinful continents, what a life
dost thou lead?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
A better than thou, I am a gentleman, thou art a
drawer.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Very true sir, and I come to&H9; draw you out by&H4; the
ears.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
O the Lord preserve thy grace: by&H4; my troth welcome
to&H4; London, now the Lord bless that&H62; sweet face of thine, O
Jesu, are you come from Wales?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Thou whoreson mad compound of majesty, by&H4; this
light, flesh, and corrupt blood, thou art welcome.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.p: How? you fat fool I scorn you.

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p:
My lord, he will&H1; drive you out of your revenge,
and turn all to&H4; a merriment if you take not the heat.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
You whoreson candlemine you, how vildly did you
speak of me now, before this honest, virtuous, civil gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Gods blessing of your good heart, and so&H52; she is by&H4; my
troth.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Didst thou hear me?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
Yea and you knew me as you did, when you ran
away by&H4; Gadshil, you knew I was at your back, and spoke it,
on&H4; purpose to&H9; try my patience.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
No&H7;, no&H7;, no&H7;, not so&H52;, I did not think thou wast within
hearing.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
I shall drive you then to&H9; confess the wilful abuse,
and then I know how to&H9; handle you.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: No&H2; abuse Hall on&H4; mine honour, no&H2; abuse.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Not to&H9; dispraise me, and call me pantler and breadchipper, and I know not what?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: No&H2; abuse Hall.

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: No&H2; abuse?

sp.speaker: Falst
sp.p:
No&H2; abuse Ned in&H4; the world, honest Ned, none, I dispraised him before the wicked, that&H3; the wicked might not fall
in&H4; love with thee: in&H4; which&H61; doing, I have done the part of a
careful friend and a true subject, and thy father is to&H9; give me
thanks for&H4; it, no&H2; abuse Hall, none Ned, none, no&H7; faith boys
none.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p:
See now whether pure fear and entire cowardice,
doth not make thee wrong this virtuous gentlewoman to&H9; close
with us&Hrp;: is she of the wicked, is thine hostess here of the wicked, or is thy boy of the wicked, or honest Bardolfe whose zeal
burns in&H4; his nose of the wicked?

sp.speaker: Poynes
sp.p: Answer thou dead elm, answer.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
The fiend hath pricked down Bardolfe irrecoverable,
and his face is Lucifers privy kitchen, where he doth nothing
but roast moult-worms, for&H3; the boy there is a good angel about
him, but the devil blinds him too.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: For&H4; the women.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
For&H4; one of them she is in&H4; hell already, and burns
poor souls: for&H4; the other I owe her&H6; money, and whether she be
damned for&H4; that&H62; I know not.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: No&H7; I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Falst.
Host.
sp.p:
All vittlers do so&H52;, what is a joint of mutton or two in&H4; a
whole Lent?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: You gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: What says your grace?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: His grace says that&H62; which&H61; his flesh rebels against.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Who&H62; knocks so&H51; loud at door? look to&H4; the door
there Francis.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Peyto, how now, what news?

sp.speaker: Peyto
sp.l: The King your father is at Weminster,
And there are twenty weak and wearied posts,
Come from the North, and as I came along
I met and overtook a dozen captains,
Bareheaded, sweating, knocking at the Taverns,
And asking every one for&H4; sir Iohn Falstaffe.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: By&H4; heaven Poines, I feele me much too blame,
So&H51; idly to&H9; profane the precious time,
When tempest of commotion like&H4; the south,
Borne with black vapour, doth begin to&H9; melt,
And drop upon&H4; our&Htp; bare unarmed heads,
Give me my sword and cloak: Falstaffe, good night.

sp.speaker: Fal.
Bar.
sp.l: You must away to&H4; court sir presently,
A dozen captains stay at door for&H4; you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Pay the musicians sirrah, farewell hostess, farewell Dol,
you see (my good wenches) how men of merit are sought after, the undeserver may sleep, when the man of action is called
on&H5;, farewell good wenches, if I be not sent away post, I will&H1;
see you again ere I go.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p:
I cannot speak: if my heart be not ready to&H9; burst: well
sweet Iacke have a care of thyself.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Farewell, farewell.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Well, fare thee well, I have known thee these twenty
nine years, come pease-cod time, but an honester, and truer
hearted man: well, fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: Mistress Tere-sheete.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: Bid mistress Tere-sheete come to&H4; my master.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
O run Doll, run, run good Doll, come, she
comes blubbered,
yea! will you come Doll?

div2.stage: Enter the King in his night-gowne alone.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Go call the Earls of Surrey and of War.
But ere they come, bid them over-read these letters,
And well consider of them, make good speed.
How many thousand of my poorest subjects,
Are at this hour asleep? O sleep! O gentle sleep!
Natures soft nurse, how have I frighted thee,
That&H3; thou no&H2; more wilt weigh my eye-lids down,
And steep my senses in&H4; forgetfulness,
Why rather sleep liest thou in&H4; smoky cribs,
Upon&H4; uneasy pallets stretching thee,
And hushed with buzzing night-flies to&H4; thy slumber,
Then in&H4; the perfumed chambers of the great,
Under the canopies of costly state,
And lulled with sound of sweetest melody?
O thou dull god, why list thou with the vile
In&H4; loathsome beds, and leavest the kingly couch,
A watch-case, or a common larum bell?
Wilt thou upon&H4; the high and giddy mass,
Seal up&H5; the shipboys eyes, and rock his brains,
In&H4; cradle of the rude imperious surge,
And in&H4; the visitation of the winds,
Who&H61; take the ruffian pillows by&H4; the top,
Curling their monstrous heads, and hanging them
With deafening clamour in&H4; the slippery clouds,
That&H3; with the hurly death itself awakes?
Canst thou, O partial sleep, give them repose,
To&H4; the wet season in&H4; an hour so&H51; rude,
And in&H4; the calmest, and most stillest night,
With all appliances and means to&H4; boot,
Deny it to&H4; a King? then (happy) low lie down,
Uneasy lies the head that&H61; wears a crown.

div2.stage: Enter Warwike, Surry, and sir Iohn Blunt.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Many good morrows to&H4; your majesty.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Is it good morrow lords?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: It is one o'clock, and past.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Why then good morrow to&H4; you all my lords.
Have you read over the letter that&H61; I sent you?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: We&Htp; have my liege.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Then you perceive the body of our&Hrp; kingdom,
How foul it is, what rank diseases grow,
And with what danger near the heart of it.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: It is but as a body yet distempered,
Which&H61; to&H4; his former strength may be restored,
With good advice and little medicine,
My Lord Northumberland will&H1; soon be cooled.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: O God that&H3; one might read the book of fate,
And see the revolution of the times,
Make mountains level, and the continent
Weary of solid firmness melt itself
Into the sea, and other times to&H9; see,
The beachy girdle of the ocean,
Too wide for&H4; Neptunes hips, how chances mocks,
And changes fill the cup of alteration,
With divers liquors! O if this were seen,
The happiest youth viewing his progress through,
What perils past, what crosses to&H9; ensue?
Would shut the book and sit him down and die:
It is not ten years gone,
Since Richard and Northumberland great friends,
Did feast together, and in&H4; two year after,
Were they at wars: it is but eight years since,
This Percie was the man nearest my soul,
Who&H61; like&H4; a brother toiled in&H4; my affairs;
And laid his love and life under my foot,
Yea for&H4; my sake, even to&H4; the eyes of Richard,
Gave him defiance: but which&H62; of you was by&H5;?
You cousin Neuel, (as I may remember)
When Richard with his eye brim full of tears,
Then checked and rated by&H4; Northumberland,
Did speak these words now proved a prophecy:
Northumberland, thou ladder by&H4; the which&H61;
My cousin Bolingbrooke ascends my throne,
(Though then (God knows) I had no&H2; such intent,
But that&H3; necessity so&H51; bowed the state,
That&H3; I and greatness were compelled to&H9; kiss.)
The time shall come, thus did he follow it,
The time will&H1; come, that&H3; foul sin gathering head,
Shall break into corruption: so&H52; went on&H5;,
Foretelling this same times condition,
And the division of our&Htp; amity.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: There is a history in&H4; all men's lives,
Figuring the natures of the times deceased:
The which&H61; observed, a man may prophecy,
With a near aim of the maine chance of things,
As yet not come to&H4; life, who&H61; in&H4; their seeds,
And weak beginning lie entreasured:
Such things become the hatch and brood of time,
And by&H4; the necessary form of this,
King Richard might create a perfect guess,
That&H3; great Northumberland then false to&H4; him,
Would of that&H62; seed grow to&H4; a greater falseness,
Which&H61; should not find a ground to&H9; root upon&H5;
Unless on&H4; you.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Are these things then necessities,
Then let us&Hrp; meet them like&H4; necessities,
And that&H62; same word even now cries out on&H4; us&Hrp;:
They say the Bishop and Northumberland,
Are fifty thousand strong.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: It cannot be my Lord,
Rumour doth double like&H4; the voice, and echo
The numbers of the feared, please it your grace,
To&H9; go to&H4; bed: upon&H4; my soul, my Lord,
The Powers that&H61; you already have sent forth,
Shall bring this prise in&H5; very easily:
To&H9; comfort you the more, I have received,
A certain instance that&H3; Glendour is dead:
Your Majesty hath been this fortnight ill,
And these unseasoned hours perforce must add
Unto your sickness.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I will&H1; take your counsel,
And were these inward wars once out of hand,
We&Hrp; would (dear Lords) unto the holy land.

div2.stage: Enter Iustice Shallow, and Iustice Silence.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.p:
Come on&H5;, come on&H5;, come on&H5; sir, give me your
hand sir, give me your hand sir, an early stirrer, by&H4; the Rood:
and how doth my good cousin Silens?

sp.speaker: Silence
sp.p: Good morrow good cousin Shallow.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.p:
And how doth my cousin your bed-fellow?
and your fairest daughter and mine, my god-daughter Ellen?

sp.speaker: Silens
sp.p: Alas, a black ouzel, cousin Shallow.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.p:
By&H4; yea, and no&H5; sir: I dare say my cousin William is become a good scholar, he is at Oxford still, is he
not?

sp.speaker: Silens
sp.p: Indeed sir to&H4; my cost.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.p:
He must then to&H4; the Inns a court shortly: I was
once of Clements Inn, where I think they will&H1; talk of mad
Shallow yet.

sp.speaker: Silens
sp.p: You were called Lusty Shallow then, cousin.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.p:
By&H4; the mass I was called anything, and I would
have done anything indeed too, and roundly too: there was
I, and little Iohn Doyt of Stafford-shire, and Black George
Barnes, and Francis Picke-bone, and Will Squele a Cotsole
man, you had not four such swing-bucklers in&H4; all the Inns
a court again: and I may say to&H4; you, we&Htp; knew where the bona
robes were, and had the best of them all at commandment:
then was Iacke Falstaffe (now sir Iohn) a boy, and Page to&H4;
Thomas Mowbray duke of Norffolke.

sp.speaker: Silens
sp.p:
Cousin, this sir Iohn that&H61; comes hither anon about
soldiers?

sp.speaker: Shall.
sp.p:
The same (sir Iohn) the very same, I see him break
Skoggins head at the Court gate, when he was a Crack, not
thus high: and the very same day did I fight with one Samson
Stock fish a Fruiterer behind Greyes Inn: Jesu, Jesu, the
mad days that&H61; I have spent! and to&H9; see how many of my old
acquaintance are dead.

sp.speaker: Silens
sp.p: We&Htp; shall all follow, cousin.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Certain, it is certain, very sure, very sure, death (as the
Psalmist saith) is certain to&H4; all, all shall die. How a good yoke
of bullocks at Samforth fair?

sp.speaker: Silens
sp.p: By&H4; my troth I was not there.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Death is certain: Is old Dooble of your town living yet?

sp.speaker: Silens
sp.p: Dead sir.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Jesu, Jesu, dead! he drew a good bow, and dead? a shot
a fine shoot: Iohn a Gaunt loved him well, and bet much
money on&H4; his head. Dead! he would have clapped in&H4; the clout at
twelve score, and carried you a forehand shaft a fourteen and
fourteen and a half, that&H3; it would have done a man's heart
good to&H9; see. How a score of Ewes now?

sp.speaker: Silens
sp.p:
Thereafter as they be, a score of good Ewes may be
worth ten pounds.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: And is old Dooble dead?

sp.speaker: Silens
sp.p:
Here come two of sir Iohn Falstaffes men, as I
think.

div2.stage: Enter Bardolfe, and one with him.

sp.p: Good morrow honest gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: I beseech you, which&H62; is Justice Shallow?

sp.speaker: Shall.
sp.p:
I am Robert Shallow sir, a poor Esquire of this
County, and one of the Kings Justices of the Peace: what is
your pleasure with me?

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p:
