My Captain, sir, commends him to&H4; you, my Captain sir Iohn Falstaffe, a tall gentleman, by&H4; heaven, and a most
gallant Leader.

sp.speaker: Shall.
sp.p:
He greets me well, sir, I knew him a good back sword
man: how doth the good knight? may I ask how my Lady
his wife doth?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
Sir, pardon, a soldier is better accommodate than
with a wife.

sp.speaker: Shallow
sp.p:
It is well said in&H4; faith sir, and it is well said indeed too, better accommodated, it is good, yea indeed is
it, good phrases, are surely, and ever were, very commendable, accommodated: it comes of accommodo, very good, a
good phrase.

sp.speaker: Bardolfe
sp.p:
Pardon me sir, I have heard the word, phrase
call you it? by&H4; this good day, I know not the phrase, but
I will&H1; maintain the word with my sword, to&H9; be a soldier-like word, and a word of exceeding good command,
by&H4; heaven: accommodated, that&H62; is, when a man is, as they
say, accommodated, or when a man is, being whereby, he
may be thought to&H9; be accommodated, which&H61; is an excellent
thing.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p:
It is very just: look, here comes good sir Iohn, give
me your good hand, give me your worships good hand,
by&H4; my troth you like&H1; well, and bear your years very well,
welcome good sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I am glad to&H9; see you well, good master Robert Shallow, master Soccard (as I think.)

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
No&H7; sir Iohn, it is my cousin Silens, in&H4; commission with
me.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Good master Silens, it well befits you should be of
the Peace.

sp.speaker: Silens
sp.p: Your good worship is welcome.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Fie, this is hot weather (gentlemen) have you provided me here half a dozen sufficient men?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Marry have we&Htp; sir, will&H1; you sit?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Let me see them I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Shall.
sp.p:
Where is the roll? where is the roll? where is the
roll? let me see, let me see, so&H3;, so&H3;, so&H3;, so&H3;, so&H3; (so&H3;, so&H3;) yea marry sir,
Rafe Mouldy, let them appear as I call, let them do so&H52;, let them
do so&H52;, let me see, where is Mouldy?

sp.speaker: Mouldy
sp.p: Here if it please you.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p:
What think you sir Iohn, a good limbed fellow, young,
strong, and of good friends.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Is thy name Mouldy?

sp.speaker: Moul.
sp.p: Yea, if it please you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: It is the more time thou wert used.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha, most excellent i'faith, things that&H61; are mouldy lack use: very singular good, i'faith well said sir Iohn, very
well said.

sp.speaker: Moul.
sp.p:
I was pricked well enough before, and you could have
let me alone, my old dame will&H1; be undone now for&H4; one to&H9; do
her&H2; husbandry, and her&H2; drudgery, you need not to&H9; have pricked
me, there are other men fitter to&H9; go out than I.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Go to&H5;, peace Mouldy, you shall go, Mouldy it is time
you were spent.

sp.speaker: Moul.
sp.p: Spent?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Peace fellow, peace, stand aside, know you where you
are? for&H4; the other sir Iohn: let me see Simon Shadow.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Yea marry, let me have him to&H9; sit under, he is like&H5; to&H9; be
a cold soldier.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Where is Shadow?

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Shadow, whose son art thou?

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: My mothers son sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Thy mothers son! like&H5; enough, and thy fathers shadow, so&H3; the son of the female is the shadow of the male: it is
often so&H52; indeed, but much of the fathers substance.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Do you like&H1; him sir Iohn?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Shadow will&H1; serve for&H4; summer, prick him, for&H3; we&Htp; have
a number of shadows, fill up&H5; the muster book.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Thomas Wart.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Wart
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Is thy name Wart?

sp.speaker: Wart
sp.p: Yea sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Thou art a very ragged wart.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Shall I prick him sir Iohn?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
It were superfluous, for&H3; apparel is built upon&H4; his back,
and the whole frame stands upon&H4; pins, prick him no&H2; more.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha, you can do it sir, you can do it, I commend
you well: Francis Feeble.

sp.speaker: Feeble
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: What trade art thou Feeble?

sp.speaker: Feeble
sp.p: A woman's tailor sir.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Shall I prick him sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
You may, but if he had been a man's tailor he would have pricked
you: wilt thou make as many holes in&H4; an enemies battle, as
thou hast done in&H4; a woman's petticoat.

sp.speaker: Feeble
sp.p: I will&H1; do my good will&H0; sir, you can have no&H2; more.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Well said good woman's tailor, well said courageous
Feeble, thou wilt be as valiant as the wrathful dove, or most
magnanimous mouse, prick the woman's tailor: well M. Shallow, deep M. Shallow.

sp.speaker: Feeble
sp.p: I would Wart might have gone sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
Feeble
sp.p: It shall suffice sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I am bound to&H4; thee reverend Feeble, who&H62; is next?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Peter Bull calf of the green.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Yea marry, let us&Htp; see Bull calf.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Eal.
sp.p: Fore God a likely fellow, come prick Bull calf till he roar again.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: O Lord, good my lord captain.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: What, dost thou roar before thou art pricked?

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p: O Lord sir, I am a diseased man.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: What disease hast thou?

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p:
A whoreson cold sir, a cough sir, which&H61; I caught with
ringing in&H5; the Kings affairs upon&H4; his coronation day sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
Shal.
Fa.
sp.p:
Come, I will&H1; go drink with you, but I cannot tarry dinner:
I am glad to&H9; see you, by&H4; my troth master Shallow.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
O sir Iohn, do you remember since we&Htp; lay all night
in&H4; the windmill in&H4; saint Georges field?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: No&H2; more of that&H62; master Shallow.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Ha, it was a merry night, and is Iane Night-work alive?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: She lives master Shallow.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: She never could away with me.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p:
Never never, she would always say, she could not abide
master Shallow.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p:
By&H4; the mass I could anger her&H6; to&H4; the heart, she was
then a bona roba, doth she hold her&H2; own well?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Old old master Shallow.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Nay she must be old, she cannot choose but be old, certain she is old, and had Robin Night-work by&H4; old Night-work,
before I came to&H4; Clements inn.

sp.speaker: Scilens
sp.p: That&H62; is fifty five year ago.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Ha cousin Scilens that&H3; thou hadst seen that&H62; that&H61; this
Knight and I have seen, ha sir Iohn, said I well?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: We&Htp; have heard the chimes at midnight M. Shallow.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p:
That&H62; we&Htp; have, that&H62; we&Htp; have, that&H62; we&Htp; have, in&H4; faith sir
Iohn we&Htp; have, our&Htp; watch-word was Hemboies, come let us&Htp; to&H4;
dinner, come let us&Htp; to&H4; dinner, Jesus the days that&H61; we&Htp; have seen,
come, come.

sp.speaker: Bul.
sp.p:
Good master corporate Bardolfe, stand my friend,
and here is four Harry ten shillings in&H4; french crowns for&H4; you, in&H4;
very truth sir, I had as lief be hanged sir as go, and yet for&H4; mine
own part sir I do not care, but rather because I am unwilling,
and for&H4; mine own part have a desire to&H9; stay with my friends,
else sir I did not care for&H4; mine own part so&H51; much.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: Go to&H5;, stand aside.

sp.speaker: Moul.
sp.p:
And good M. corporal captain, for&H4; my old dames
sake stand my friend, she has nobody to&H9; do anything about
her&H6; when I am gone, and she is old and cannot help herself,
you shall have forty sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Go to&H5;, stand aside.

sp.speaker: Feeble
sp.p:
By&H4; my troth I care not, a man can die but once, we&Htp;
owe God a death, I will&H1; never bear a base mind, if it be my
destiny: so&H3;, if it be not, so&H3;, no&H2; man's too good to&H9; serve his prince,
and let it go which way it will, he that dies this year is quit for
the next.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Well said, thou art a good fellow.

sp.speaker: Feeble
sp.p: Faith I will&H1; bear no&H2; base mind.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Come sir, which&H62; men shall I have?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Four of which&H61; you please.

sp.speaker: Bar
sp.p: Sir, a word with you, I have three pound to&H9; free Mouldy and Bull calf.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Go to&H5;, well.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Come sir Iohn, which&H62; four will&H1; you have?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Do you choose for&H4; me.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Marry then, Mouldy, Bull calf, Feeble, and Sadow.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Mouldy and Bull calf, for&H4; you Mouldy stay at home, till
you are past service: and for&H4; your part Bull calf, grow till you
come unto it, I will&H1; none of you.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Sir Iohn, sir Iohn, do not yourself wrong, they are
your likeliest men, and I would have you served with the
best.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Will&H1; you tell me (master Shallow) how to&H9; choose a man?
care I for&H4; the limb, the thews, the stature, bulk and big assemblance of a man: give me the spirit M. Shalow: here is Wart,
you see what a ragged appearance it is, a shall charge you, and
discharge you with the motion of a pewterers hammer, come
off and on&H5; swifter than he that&H61; gibbets on&H4; the brewers bucket:
and this same half faced fellow Shadow, give me this man, he
presents no&H2; mark to&H4; the enemy, the foeman may with as great
aim level at the edge of a pen-knife, and for&H4; a retreat how
swiftly will&H1; this Feeble the woman's Tailor run off? O give
me the spare men, and spare me the great ones, put me a
caliver into Warts hand Bardolfe.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Hold Wart, trauers thas, thas, thas.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Come manage me your caliver: so&H3;, very well, go to&H5;, very
good, exceeding good, O give me always a little lean, old
chopped Ballde, shot: well said i'faith Wart, thou art a good scab,
hold, there is a tester for&H4; thee.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
He is not his crafts-master, he doth not do it right; I
remember at Mile-end-greene, when I lay at Clements Inn,
I was then sir Dagonet in&H4; Arthurs show, there was a little
quiver fellow, and he would manage you his piece thus, and he
would about and about, and come you in&H5;, and come you in&H5;,
rah, tah, tah, would he say, bounce would he say, and away again
would he go, and again would he come: I shall never see such a
fellow.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
These fellows will&H1; do well M. Shallow, God keep
you M. Scilens, I will&H1; not use many words with you, fare you
well gentlemen both, I thank you, I must a dozen mile tonight:
Bardolfe, give the soldiers coats.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Sir Iohn, the Lord bless you, God prosper your affairs, God send us&Htp; peace at your return, visit our&Htp; house, let
our&Htp; old acquaintance be renewed, peradventure I will&H1; with ye
to&H4; the court.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Fore God would you would.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Go to&H5;, I have spoke at a word, God keep you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Fare you well gentle gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
On&H5; Bardolfe, lead the men away, as I return I will&H1;
fetch off these justices, I do see the bottom of justice Shallow,
Lord, Lord, how subject we&Htp; old men are to&H4; this vice of lying,
this same starved justice hath done nothing but prate to&H4; me,
of the wildness of his youth, and the feats he hath done about Turn-bull street, and every third word a lie, more due paid
to&H4; the hearer then the Turkes tribute, I do remember him
at Clements Inn, like&H4; a man made after supper of a cheese paring, when he was naked, he was for&H4; all the world like&H4; a forked
reddish, with a head fantastically carved upon&H4; it with a knife,
he was so&H51; forlorn, that&H3; his dimensions to&H4; any thick sight were
invincible, he was the very genius of famine, yet lecherous as a
monkey, and the whores called him mandrake, he came over in&H4; the
rearward of the fashion, and sung those tunes to&H4; the ouerschutcht housewives, that&H61; he heard the Car-men whistle, and
swear they were his fancies or his good-nights, and now is
this vices dagger become a squire, and talks as familiarly of
Iohn a Gaunt, as if he had been sworn brother to&H4; him, and
I will&H1; be sworn he never saw him but once in&H4; the tilt-yard, and then
he burst his head for&H4; crowding among the Marshal's men, I
saw it and told Iohn a Gaunt he beat his own name, for&H3; you
might have thrust him and all his apparel into an eel-skin, the
case of a treble hautboy was a mansion for&H4; him at Court, and
now has he land and beefs. Well, I will&H1; be acquainted with him
if I return, and it shall go hard, but I will&H1; make him a philosophers
two stones to&H4; me, if the young Dase be a bait for&H4; the old Pike,
I see no&H2; reason in&H4; the law of nature but I may snap at him, till
Time shape, and there an end.

div2.stage: Enter the Archbishop, Mowbray, Bardolfe, Hastings, within the forrest of Gaultree.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: What is this forest called?

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: It is Gaultree forest, if it shall please your grace.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Here stand, my lords, and send discoverers forth,
To&H9; know the numbers of our&Htp; enemies:

sp.speaker: Hastings
sp.l: We&Htp; have sent forth already.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: It is well done,
My friends and brethren (in&H4; these great affairs)
I must acquaint you, that&H3; I have received
New dated letters from Northumberland,
Their cold intent, tenure, and substance thus:
Here doth he wish his person, with such powers,
As might hold sortance with his quality,
The which&H61; he could not levy: whereupon
He is retired to&H9; ripe his growing fortunes,
To&H4; Scotland, and concludes in&H4; hearty prayers,
That&H3; your attempts may over-live the hazard
And fearful meeting of their opposite.

sp.speaker: Mowb.
sp.l: Thus do the hopes we&Htp; have in&H4; him, touch ground,
And dash themselves to&H4; pieces.

sp.speaker: Hastings
sp.l: Now, what news?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: West of this forest, scarcely off a mile,
In&H4; goodly form comes on&H5; the enemy,
And by&H4; the ground they hide, I judge their number
Upon&H4;, or near the rate of thirty thousand.

sp.speaker: Mowbray
sp.l: The just proportion that&H61; we&Htp; gave them out,
Let us&Htp; sway on&H5;, and face them in&H4; the field.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: What well appointed Leader fronts us&Htp; here?

sp.speaker: Mowbray
sp.l: I think it is my lord of Westmerland.

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: Health and fair greeting from our&Htp; General,
The prince lord Iohn and duke of Lancaster.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Say on&H5; my lord of Westmerland in&H4; peace,
What doth concern your coming?

sp.speaker: We.
sp.l: Then my L. unto your Grace do I in&H4; chief address
The substance of my speech: if that&H3; rebellion
Came like&H4; itself, in&H4; base and abject routs,
Led on&H5; by&H4; bloody youth, guarded with rage,
And countenanced by&H4; boys and beggary.
I say, if damned commotion so&H52; appear,
In&H4; his true, native, and most proper shape,
You, reverend father, and these noble Lords,
Had not been here to&H9; dress the ugly form
Of base and bloody Insurrection
With your fair Honours. You (lord Archbishop)
Whose Sea is by&H4; a civil peace maintained,
Whose beard the silver hand of Peace hath touched,
Whose learning and good letters Peace hath tutored,
Whose white investments figure innocence,
The Dove, and very blessed spirit of peace.
Wherefore do you so&H51; ill translate yourself
Out of the speech of peace that&H61; bears such grace,
Into the harsh and boisterous tongue of war?
Turning your books to&H4; graves, your ink to&H4; blood,
Your pens to&H4; lances, and your tongue divine,
To&H4; a loud trumpet, and a point of war?

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: Wherefore do I this? so&H52; the question stands:
Briefly, to&H4; this end we&Htp; are all diseased:
The dangers of the day is but newly gone,
Whose memory is written on&H4; the earth,
With yet appearing blood, and the examples
Of every minutes instance (present now,)
Hath put us&Htp; in&H4; these ill-beseeming arms,
Not to&H9; break peace, or any branch of it,
But to&H9; establish here a peace indeed,
Concurring both in&H4; name and quality.

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: When ever yet was your appeal denied
Wherein have you been galled by&H4; the King?
What peer hath been suborned to&H9; grate on&H4; you?
That&H3; you should seal this lawless bloody book
Of forged rebellion with a seal divine,
And consecrate commotions bitter edge.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: My brother General, the common wealth
To&H4; brother born an household cruelty,
I make my quarrel in&H4; particular.

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: There is no&H2; need of any such redress,
Or if there were, it not belongs to&H4; you.

sp.speaker: Mowbray
sp.l: why not to&H4; him in&H4; part, and to&H4; us&Htp; all
That&H61; feele the bruises of the days before?
And suffer the condition of these times,
To&H9; lay a heavy and unequal hand
Upon&H4; our&Htp; honours.

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: But this is mere digression from my purpose.
Here come I from our&Htp; princely general,
To&H9; know your griefs, to&H9; tell you from his Grace,
That&H3; he will&H1; give you audience, and wherein
It shall appear that&H3; your demands are just,
You shall enjoy them, everything set off
That&H61; might so&H51; much as think you enemies.

sp.speaker: Mowbray
sp.l: But he hath forced us&Htp; to&H9; compel this offer,
And it proceeds from policy, not love.

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: Mowbray, you overween to&H9; take it so&H52;:
This offer comes from mercy, not from fear:
For&H3; lo, within a ken our&Htp; army lies:
Upon&H4; mine honour, all too confident
To&H9; give admittance to&H4; a thought of fear:
Our&Htp; battle is more full of names than yours,
Our&Htp; men more perfect in&H4; the use of arms,
Our&Htp; armour all as strong, our&Htp; cause the best:
Then Reason will&H1; our&Htp; hearts should be as good:
Say you not then, our&Htp; offer is compelled.

sp.speaker: Mow.
sp.l: Well, by&H4; my will&H0;, we&Htp; shall admit no&H2; parley.

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: That&H62; argues but the shame of your offence,
A rotten case abides no&H2; handling.

sp.speaker: Hastings
sp.l: Hath the prince Iohn a full commission,
In&H4; very ample virtue of his father,
To&H9; hear, and absolutely to&H9; determine
Of what conditions we&Htp; shall stand upon&H5;?

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: That&H62; is intended in&H4; the Generals name,
I muse you make so&H51; slight a question.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Then take, my lord of Westmerland, this schedule,
For&H3; this contains our&Htp; general grievances,
Each several article herein redressed.
All members of our&Htp; cause both here and hence,
That&H61; are ensinewed to&H4; this action,
Acquitted by&H4; a true substantial form,
And present execution of our&Htp; wills,
To&H4; us&Htp; and our purposes confined,
We&Htp; come within our&Htp; awful banks again,
And knit our&Htp; powers to&H4; the arm of peace.

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: This will&H1; I show the General, please you Lords,
In&H4; sight of both our&Htp; battles we&Htp; may meet,
At either end in&H4; peace, which&H61; God so&H52; frame,
Or to&H4; the place of difference call the swords,
Which&H61; must decide it.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: My lord, we&Htp; will&H1; do so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Mou
sp.l: There is a thing within my bosom tells me
That&H3; no&H2; conditions of our&Htp; peace can stand.

sp.speaker: Hastings
sp.l: Fear you not, that&H3; if we&Htp; can make our&Htp; peace,
Upon&H4; such large terms, and so&H51; absolute,
As our&Htp; conditions shall consist upon&H5;,
Our&Htp; peace shall stand as firm as rocky mountains.

sp.speaker: Moub.
sp.l: Yea but our&Htp; valuation shall be such,
That&H3; every slight, and false derived cause,
Yea every idle, nice, and wanton reason,
Shall to&H4; the King taste of this action,
That&H3; were our&Htp; royal faiths martyrs in&H4; love,
We&Htp; shall be winnowed with so&H51; rough a wind,
That&H3; even our&Htp; corn shall seem as light as chaff,
And good from bad find no&H2; partition.

sp.speaker: Bish.
sp.l: No&H7;, no&H7;, my lord, note this, the King is weary
Of dainty and such picking grievances,
For&H3; he hath found, to&H9; end one doubt by&H4; death,
Revives two greater in&H4; the heirs of life:
And therefore will&H1; he wipe his tables clean,
And keep no&H2; telltale to&H4; his memory,
That&H61; may repeat, and history his loss,
To&H4; new remembrance: for&H3; full well he knows,
He cannot so&H51; precisely weed this land,
As his misdoubts present occasion,
His foes are so&H51; enrooted with his friends,
That&H3; plucking to&H9; unfix an enemy,
He doth unfasten so&H52;, and shake a friend,
So&H3; that&H3; this land, like an offensive wife,
That&H61; hath enraged him on&H5; to&H9; offer strokes,
As he is striking, holds his infant up&H5;,
And hangs resolved correction in&H4; the arm,
That&H61; was upreared to&H4; execution.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: Besides, the King hath wasted all his rods,
On&H4; late offenders, that&H3; he now doth lack
The very instruments of chastisement,
So&H3; that&H3; his power, like&H5; to&H4; a fangless lion,
May offer, but not hold.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: It is very true,
And therefore be assured, my good Lord Marshall,
If we&Htp; do now make our&Htp; atonement well,
Our&Htp; peace will&H1; like&H4; a broken limb united,
Grow stronger for&H4; the breaking.

sp.speaker: Mow.
sp.l: Be it so, here is returned my lord of Westmerland.

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: The prince is here at hand, pleaseth your Lordship
To&H9; meet his grace just distance between our&Htp; armies.

div2.stage: Enter Prince Iohn and his armie.

sp.speaker: Mow.
sp.l: Your grace of York, in&H4; Gods name then set forward.

sp.speaker: Bishop.
sp.l: Before, and greet his grace (my lord) we&Htp; come.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: You are well encountered here, my cousin Mowbray,
Good day to&H4; you, gentle Lord Archbishop,
And so&H3; to&H4; you Lord Hastings, and to&H4; all.
My Lord of Yorke, it better showed with you,
When that&H3; your flock assembled by&H4; the bell,
Encircled you, to&H9; hear with reverence,
Your exposition on&H4; the holy text,
That&H3; now to&H9; see you here, an iron man talking,
Cheering a rout of rebels with your drum,
Turning the word to&H4; sword, and life to&H4; death.
That&H62; man that&H61; sits within a monarchs heart,
And ripens in&H4; the sun-shine of his favour,
Would he abuse the countenance of the King:
Alack what mischiefs might he set abroach,
In&H4; shadow of such greatness? with you Lord bishop
It is even so&H52;, who&H62; hath not heard it spoken,
How deep you were within the books of God,
To&H4; us&Hrp; the speaker in&H4; his parliament,
To&H4; us&Hrp; the imagine voice of God himself,
The very opener and intelligencer,
Between the grace, the sanctities of heaven,
And our&Hrp; dull workings? O who&H62; shall believe,
But you misuse the reverence of your place,
Imply the countenance and grace of heaven,
As a false favourite doth his princes name:
In&H4; deeds dishonourable you have taken up&H5;,
Under the counterfeited zeal of God,
The subjects of his substitute my father,
And both against the peace of heaven and him,
Have here upswarmed them.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Good my Lord of Lancaster,
I am not here against your fathers peace,
But as I told my lord of Westmerland,
The time misordered doth in&H4; common sense,
Crowd us&Htp; and crush us&Htp; to&H4; this monstrous form,
To&H9; hold our&Htp; safety up&H5;: I sent your grace,
The parcels and particulars of our&Htp; grief,
The which&H61; hath been with scorn shoved from the court,
Whereon this Hydra, son of war is born,
Whose dangerous eyes may well be charmed asleep,
With grant of our&Htp; most just, and right desires,
And true obedience of this madness cured,
Stoop tamely to&H4; the foot of majesty.

sp.speaker: Mow.
sp.l: If not, we&Htp; ready are to&H9; try our&Htp; fortunes,
To&H4; the last man.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: And though we&Htp; here fall down,
We&Htp; have supplies to&H9; second our&Htp; attempt,
If they miscarry, theirs shall second them,
And so&H3; success of mischief shall be born,
And heir from heir shall hold his quarrel up&H5;,
Whiles England shall have generation.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: You are too shallow Hastings, much too shallow,
To&H9; sound the bottom of the after times.

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: Pleaseth your grace to&H9; answer them directly,
How far forth you do like&H1; their articles.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: I like&H1; them all, and do allow them well,
And swear here by&H4; the honour of my blood,
My fathers purposes have been mistook,
And some about him have too lavishly,
Wrested his meaning and authority.
My Lord, these griefs shall be with speed redressed,
Upon&H4; my soul they shall, if this may please you,
Discharge your powers unto their several counties,
As we&Hrp; will&H1; ours, and here between the armies,
Let us&Htp; drink together friendly and embrace,
That&H3; all their eyes may bear those tokens home,
Of our&Htp; restored love and amity.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: I take your princely word for&H4; these redresses,
I give it you, and will&H1; maintain my word,
And thereupon I drink unto your grace.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Go Captain, and deliver to&H4; the army
This news of peace, let them have pay, and part.
I know it will&H1; well please them, hie thee captain.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: To&H4; you my noble lord of Westmerland.

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: I pledge your grace, and if you knew what pains,
I have bestowed to&H9; breed this present peace,
You would drink freely, but my love to&H4; ye
Shall show itself more openly hereafter.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: I do not doubt you.

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: I am glad of it,
Health to&H4; my Lord, and gentle cousin Mowbray.

sp.speaker: Mow.
sp.l: You wish me health in very happy season,
For I am on the sudden something ill.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Against ill chances men are ever merry,
But heaviness fore-runs the good event.

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: Therefore be merry cuz, since sudden sorrow
Serves to&H9; say thus, some good thing comes tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Believe me I am passing light in&H4; spirit.

sp.speaker: Mow.
sp.l: So&H51; much the worse if your own rule be true.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: The word of peace is rendered, hark how they shout.

sp.speaker: Mow.
sp.l: This had been cheerful after victory.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: A peace is of the nature of a conquest,
For&H3; then both parties nobly are subdued,
And neither party looser.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Go my lord,
And let our&Hrp; army be discharged too,
And, good my lord, so&H52; please you, let our&Hrp; trains
March by&H4; us&Hrp;, that&H3; we&Hrp; may peruse the men,
We&Hrp; should have coapt withal.

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: Go, good Lord Hastings,
And ere they be dismissed, let them march by&H5;.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: I trust Lords we&Htp; shall lie tonight together:
Now cousin, wherefore stands our&Hrp; army still?

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: The Leaders having charge from you to&H9; stand,
Will&H1; not go off until they hear you speak.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: They know their duties.

sp.speaker: Hastings
sp.l: My lord, our&Htp; army is dispersed already,
Like&H4; youthful steers unyoked they take their courses,
East, west, north, south, or like&H4; a school broke up&H5;,
Each hurries toward his home, and sporting place.

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: Good tidings my lord Hastings, for&H4; the which&H61;
I do arrest thee traitor of high treason,
And you lord Archbishop, and you lord Mowbray,
Of capital treason I attach you both.

sp.speaker: Mowbray
sp.l: Is this proceeding just and honourable?

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: Is your assembly so&H52;?

sp.speaker: Bishop
sp.l: will&H1; you thus break your faith?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: I pawned thee none,
I promised you redress of these same grievances
Whereof you did complain, which&H61; by&H4; mine honour
I will&H1; perform, with a most christian care.
But for&H4; you rebels, look to&H9; taste the due
Meet for&H4; rebellion:
Most shallowly did you these arms commence,
Fondly brought here, and foolishly sent hence.
Strike up&H5; our&Hrp; drums, pursue the scattered stray:
God, and not we&Hrp;, hath safely fought today:
Some guard this traitor to&H4; the block of death,
Treasons true bed, and yielder up&H5; of breath.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
what is your name sir, of what condition are you, and
of what place?

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.p:
I am a Knight sir, and my name is Coleuile of the
Dale.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
well then, Colleuile is your name, a Knight is your degree, and your place the dale: Coleuile shall be still your name,
a traitor your degree, and the dungeon your place, a place deep
enough, so&H52; shall you be still Colleuile of the Dale.

sp.speaker: Colle.
sp.p: Are not you sir Iohn Falstaffe?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
As good a man as he sir, whoever I am: do ye yield
sir, or shall I sweat for&H4; you? if I do sweat, they are the drops
of thy lovers, and they weep for&H4; thy death, therefore rouse
up&H5; fear and trembling, and do observance to&H4; my mercy.

sp.speaker: Colle.
sp.p:
I think you are sir Iohn Falstaffe, and in&H4; that&H62; thought
yield me.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I have a whole school of tongues in&H4; this belly of mine,
and not a tongue of them all speaks any other word but my
name, and I had but a belly of any indifferency, I were simply
the most active fellow in&H4; Europe: my womb, my womb, my
womb undoes me, here comes our&Htp; General.

div2.stage: Enter Iohn Westmerland, and the rest. Retraite

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: The heat is past, follow no&H2; further now,
Call in&H5; the powers good cousin Westmerland.
Now Falstaffe, where have you been all this while?
When everything is ended, then you come:
These tardy tricks of yours will&H1; on&H4; my life
One time or other break some gallows back.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I would be sorry my lord, but it should be thus: I
never knew yet but Rebuke and Check, was the reward of
Valour: do you think me a swallow, an arrow, or a bullet? have
I in&H4; my poor and old motion the expedition of thought? I
have speeded hither with the very extremest inch of possibility, I have foundered ninescore and odd posts, and here travel
tainted as I am, have in&H4; my pure and immaculate valour, taken sir Iohn Colleuile of the Dale, a most furious Knight and
valorous enemy,: but what of that&H62;? he saw me, and yielded,
that&H3; I may justly say with the hook-nosed fellow of Rome,
there cousin, I came, saw, and overcame.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p: It was more of his courtesy than your deserving.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
I know not, here he is, and here I yield him, and I
beseech your grace let it be booked with the rest of this days
deeds, or by&H4; the Lord, I will&H1; have it in&H4; a particular ballad else,
with mine own picture on&H4; the top of it, (Coleuile kissing my
foot) to&H4; the which&H61; course, if I be enforced, if you do not all
show like&H4; guilt two pences to&H4; me, and I in&H4; the clear sky of
Fame, over-shine you as much as the full moon doth the cinders of the element, (which&H61; show like&H4; pins heads to&H4; her&H6;) believe not the word of the noble: therefore let me have right,
and let Desert mount.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Thine is too heavy to&H9; mount.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Let it shine then.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Thine is too thick to&H9; shine.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Let it do something, my good lord, that&H61; may do me
good, and call it what you will&H1;.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: Is thy name Colleuile?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: It is my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: A famous rebel art thou Colleuile.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: And a famous true subject took him.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I am my lord but as my betters are,
That&H61; led me hither, had they been ruled by&H4; me,
You should have won them dearer than you have.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I know not how they sold themselves, but thou like&H4; a
kind fellow gavest thyself away gratis, and I thank thee for&H4;
thee.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Now, have you left pursuit?

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: retreat is made, and execution stayed.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Send Colleuile with his confederates
To&H4; Yorke to&H4; present execution,
Blunt lead him hence, and see you guard him sure.
And now dispatch we&Hrp; toward the court my lords,
I hear the King my father is sore sick,
Our&Hrp; news shall go before us&Hrp; to&H4; his majesty,
Which&H61; cousin you shall bear to&H9; comfort him,
And we&Hrp; with sober speed will&H1; follow you.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.l: My Lord, I beseech you give me leave to&H9; go through
Glostershire, and when you come to&H4; court, stand my good lord
in&H4; your good report.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Fare you well Falstaffe, I, in&H4; my condition, shall better
speak of you than you deserve.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I would you had the wit, it were better than your dukedom, good faith this same young sober blooded boy doth not
love me, nor a man cannot make him laugh, but that&H62; is no&H2; marvel,
he drinks no&H2; wine, there is never none of these demure boys
come to&H4; any proof, for&H3; thin drink doth so&H51; over-cool their
blood, and making many fish meals, that&H3; they fall into a kind
of male green sickness, and then when they marry, they get
wenches, they are generally fools and cowards, which&H61; some
of us&Htp; should be too, but for&H4; inflammation: a good sherry sack
hath a two fold operation in&H4; it, it ascends me into the brain,
dries me there all the foolish, and dull, and cruddy vapours which&H61;
environ it, makes it apprehensive, quick, forgetful, full of
nimble, fiery, and delectable shapes, which&H61; delivered over to&H4;
the voice, the tongue, which&H61; is the birth, becomes excellent
wit. The second property of your excellent sherry, is the warming of the blood, which&H61; before (cold and settled,) left the liver
white and pale, which&H61; is the badge of pusillanimity and cowardice: but the sherry warms it, and makes it course from the
inwards to&H4; the parts extremes, it illumineth the face, which&H61;
as a beacon, gives warning to&H4; all the rest of this little kingdom
man to&H4; arm, and then the vital commoners, and inland petty
spirits, muster me all to&H4; their captain, the heart: who&H61; great, and
puffed up&H5; with this retinue, doth any deed of courage: and this
valour comes of sherry, so&H3; that&H3; skill in&H4; the weapon is nothing
without sack (for&H3; that&H62; sets it a-work) and learning a mere
hoard of gold kept by&H4; a devil, till sack commences it, and
sets it in&H4; act and use. Hereof comes it, that&H3; Prince Harry is
valiant, for&H3; the cold blood he did naturally inherit of his father, he hath like&H4; lean, sterile, and bare land, manured, husbanded and tilled, with excellent endeavour of drinking good
and good store of fertile sherry, that&H3; he is become very hot
and valiant. If I had a thousand sons, the first human principle I would teach them, should be, to&H9; forswear thin potations, and to&H9; addict themselves to&H4; sack. How now Bardolfe?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: The army is discharged all, and gone.

sp.speaker: Fal.

div2.stage: Enter the King, Warwike, Kent, Thomas duke of Clarence, Humphrey of Gloucester.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Now lords, if God doth give successful end,
To&H4; this debate that&H61; bleedeth at our&Hrp; doors,
We&Hrp; will&H1; our&Hrp; youth lead on&H5; to&H4; higher fields,
And draw no&H2; swords but what are sanctified:
Our&Hrp; navy is addressed, our&Hrp; power collected,
Our&Hrp; substitutes in&H4; absence well invested,
And everything lies level to&H4; our&Hrp; wish,
Only we&Hrp; want a little personal strength:
And pause us&Hrp; till these rebels now afoot,
Come underneath the yoke of government.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Both which&H61; we&Htp; doubt not, but your majesty
Shall soon enjoy.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Humphrey my son of Gloster, where is the prince
your brother?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I think he is gone to&H9; hunt, my lord, at Winsor.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: And how accompanied?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I do not know, my lord.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Is not his brother Thomas of Clarence with him?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: No&H7;, my good lord, he is in&H4; presence here.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: What would my lord and father?

sp.speaker: Kin
sp.l: Nothing but well to&H4; thee Thomas of Clarence,
How chance thou art not with the prince thy brother?
He loves thee, and thou dost neglect him, Thomas,
Thou hast a better place in&H4; his affection
Than all thy brothers, cherish it my boy:
And noble offices thou mayest effect
Of mediation after I am dead,
Between his greatness and thy other brethren:
Therefore omit him not, blunt not his love,
Nor loose the good advantage of his grace,
By&H4; seeming cold, or careless of his will&H0;,
For&H3; he is gracious if he be observed,
He hath a tear for&H4; pity, and a hand,
Open as day for&H4; meeting charity,
Yet notwithstanding being incensed, he is flint,
As humorous as winter, and as sudden
As flaws congealed in&H4; the spring of day:
His temper therefore must be well observed,
Chide him for&H4; faults, and do it reverently,
When you perceive his blood inclined to&H4; mirth:
But being moody, give him time and scope,
Till that&H3; his passions, like&H4; a whale on&H4; ground
Confound themselves with working, learn this Thomas,
And thou shalt prove a shelter to&H4; thy friends,
A hoop of gold to&H9; bind thy brothers in&H5;,
That&H3; the united vessel of their blood,
(Mingled with venom of suggestion,
As force perforce, the age will&H1; pour it in&H5;,)
Shall never leak, though it do work as strong,
As Aconitum, or rash gunpowder.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I shall observe him with all care and love.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Why art thou not at Winsore with him Thomas?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: He is not there today, he dines in&H4; London.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: And how accompanied?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: With Poines, and other his continual followers.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Most subject is the fattest soil to&H4; weeds,
And he, the noble image of my youth,
Is overspread with them, therefore my grief
Stretches itself beyond the hour of death:
The blood weeps from my heart when I do shape,
In&H4; forms imaginary, the unguided days,
And rotten times that&H61; you shall look upon&H5;,
When I am sleeping with my ancestors:
For&H3; when his head-strong riot hath no&H2; curb,
When rage and hot blood are his counsellors,
When means and lavish manners meet together,
O with what wings shall his affections fly,
Towards fronting peril and opposed decay?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: My gracious Lord, you look beyond him quite,
The prince but studies his companions,
Like&H4; a strange tongue wherein to&H9; gain the language:
It is needfull that&H3; the most immodest word,
Be looked upon&H5; and learnt, which&H61; once attained,
Your highness knows comes to&H4; no&H2; further use,
But to&H9; be known and hated: so&H3;, like&H4; gross terms,
The prince will&H1; in&H4; the perfectness of time,
Cast off his followers, and their memory
Shall as a pattern, or a measure live,
By&H4; which&H61; his grace must mete the lives of other,
Turning past-evils to&H4; advantages.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: It is seldom when the bee doth leave her&H2; comb,
In&H4; the dead carrion: who&H62; is here, Westmerland?

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: Health to&H4; my sovereign, and new happiness
Added to&H4; that&H62; that&H3; I am to&H9; deliver,
Prince Iohn your son doth kiss your graces hand.
Mowbray, the Bishop, Scroope, Hastings, and all,
Are brought to&H4; the correction of your law:
There is not now a rebels sword unsheathed,
But Peace puts forth her&H2; olive everywhere,
The manner how this action hath been born,
Here at more leisure may your highness read,
With every course in&H4; his particular.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: O Westmerland, thou art a summer bird,
Which&H61; ever in&H4; the haunch of winter sings
The lifting up&H5; of day: look here is more news.

sp.speaker: Harc.
sp.l: From enemies, heavens keep your majesty,
And when they stand against you, may they fall
As those that&H61; I am come to tell you of:
The Earl Northumberland, and the Lord Bardolfe,
With a great power of English, and of Scots,
Are by&H4; the shrieve of Yorkshire overthrown,
The manner, and true order of the fight,
This packet, please it you, contains at large,

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: And wherefore should these good news make me sick?
Will&H1; Fortune never come with both hands full.
But wet her&H2; fair words still in&H4; foulest terms?
She either gives a stomach, and no&H2; food,
Such are the poor in&H4; health: or else a feast,
And takes away the stomach, such are the rich
That&H61; have abundance, and enjoy it not:
I should rejoice now at this happy news,
And now my sight fails, and my brain is giddy,
O me, come near me, now I am much ill.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Comfort your majesty.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: O my royal father!

sp.speaker: West.
sp.l: My sovereign Lord, cheer up&H5; yourself, look up&H5;.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Be patient princes, you do know these fits
Are with his highness very ordinary.
Stand from him, give him air, he will&H1; straight be well.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: No&H7;, no&H7;, he cannot long hold out these pangs,
The incessant care and labour of his mind,
Hath wrought the Mure that&H61; should confine it in&H5;,
So&H51; thin that&H3; life looks through.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: The people fear me, for&H3; they do observe
Unfathered heirs, and loathly births of nature,
The seasons change their manners, as the year
Had found some months asleep, and leapt them over.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: The river hath thrice flowed, no&H2; ebb between,
And the old folk, (Times doting chronicles,)
Say, it did so&H52; a little time before
That&H3; our&Htp; great grandsire Edward, sicked and died.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Speak lower, princes, for&H3; the King recovers.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: This apoplexy will&H1; certain be his end.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I pray you take me up&H5;, and bear me hence,
Into some other chamber.
Let there be no&H2; noise made, my gentle friends,
Unless some dull and favourable hand
Will&H1; whisper music to&H4; my weary spirit.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Call for the music in&H4; the other room.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Set me the crown upon&H4; my pillow here.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: His eye is hollow, and he changes much.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Less noise, less noise.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Who&H62; saw the duke of Clarence?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I am here brother, full of heaviness.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: How now, rain within doors, and none abroad?
How doth the King?

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Exceeding ill.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: Heard he the good news yet? tell it him.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: He altered much upon&H4; the hearing it,

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: If he be sick with joy, he will&H1; recover without physic.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Not so&H51; much noise my Lords, sweet prince, speak
low, the King your father is disposed to&H9; sleep.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Let us&Htp; withdraw into the other room.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Wilt please your Grace to&H9; go along with us&Htp;?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: No&H7;, I will&H1; sit and watch here by&H4; the King.
Why doth the Crown lie there upon&H4; his pillow,
Being so&H51; troublesome a bedfellow?
O polished perturbation! golden care!
That&H61; keepest the ports of Slumber open wide
To&H4; many a watchful night, sleep with it now!
Yet not so&H51; sound, and half so&H51; deeply sweet,
As he whose brow (with homely biggin bound)
Snores out the watch of night. O majesty!
When thou dost pinch thy bearer, thou dost sit
Like&H4; a rich armour worn in&H4; heat of day,
That&H61; scaldest with safety (by&H4; his gates of breath)
There lies a downy feather which&H61; stirs not,
Did he suspire, that&H3; light and weightless down
Perforce must move my gracious lord my father:
This sleep is sound indeed, this is a sleep,
That&H61; from this golden Rigoll hath divorced
So&H51; many English Kings, thy due from me,
Is tears and heavy sorrows of the blood,
Which&H61; nature, love, and filial tenderness
Shall (O dear father) pay thee plenteously:
My due from thee is this imperial Crown,
Which&H61; as immediate from thy place and blood,
Derives itself to&H4; me: lo where it sits,
Which&H61; God shall guard, and put the worlds whole strength
Into one giant arm, it shall not force,
This lineal honour from me, this from thee
Will&H1; I to&H4; mine leave, as it is left to&H4; me.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Warwicke, Gloucester, Clarence.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Doth the King call?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: What would your Majesty?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Why did you leave me here alone, my lords?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: We&Htp; left the prince my brother here my liege, who&H61; undertook to&H9; sit and watch by&H4; you.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: The prince of Wales, where is he? let me see him: he
is not here.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: This door is open, he is gone this way.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: He came not through the chamber where we&Htp; stayed.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Where is the Crown? who&H62; took it from my pillow?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: When we&Htp; withdrew, my liege, we&Htp; left it here.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: The Prince hath taken it hence, go seek him out:
Is he so&H51; hasty, that&H3; he doth suppose my sleep my death?
Find him, my lord of Warwicke, chide him hither.
This part of his conjoins with my disease,
And helps to&H9; end me: see, sons, what things you are,
How quickly nature falls into revolt,
When gold becomes her&H2; object?
For&H4; this, the foolish over-careful fathers
Have broke their sleep with thoughts,
Their brains with care, their bones with industry:
For&H4; this they have engrossed and piled up&H5;,
The cankered heaps of strange achieved gold:
For&H4; this they have been thoughtful to&H9; invest
Their sons with arts and martial exercises,
When like&H4; the bee toiling from every flower,
Our&Hrp; thigh, packed with wax, our&Hrp; mouths with honey,
We&Hrp; bring it to&H4; the hive: and like&H4; the bees,
Are murdered for&H4; our&Hrp; pains, this bitter taste
Yields his engrossments to&H4; the ending father,
Now where is he that&H61; will&H1; not stay so&H51; long,
Till his friend sickness hands determined me.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: My Lord, I found the prince in&H4; the next room,
Washing with kindly tears, his gentle cheeks,
With such a deep demeanour in&H4; great sorrow,
That&H3; tyranny, which&H61; never quaffed but blood,
Would by&H4; beholding him, have washed his knife,
With gentle eye-drops, he is coming hither.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: But wherefore did he take away the crown?
Lo where he comes, come hither to&H4; me Harry,
Depart the chamber, leave us&Htp; here alone.

sp.speaker: Harry
sp.l: I never thought to&H9; hear you speak again.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thy wish was father (Harry,) to&H4; that&H62; thought
I stay too long by&H4; thee, I weary thee,
Dost thou so&H51; hunger for&H4; mine empty chair,
That&H3; thou wilt needs invest thee with my honours,
Before thy hour be ripe! O foolish youth,
Thou seekst the greatness that&H61; will&H1; overwhelm thee,
Stay but a little, for&H3; my cloud of dignity
Is held from falling with so&H51; weak a wind,
That&H3; it will&H1; quickly drop: my day is dim,
Thou hast stolen that&H62;, which&H61; after some few hours,
Were thine, without offence, and at my death,
Thou hast sealed up&H5; my expectation,
Thy life did manifest thou lovedest me not,
And thou wilt have me die, assured of it,
Thou hidest a thousand daggers in&H4; thy thoughts,
Whom thou hast whetted on&H4; thy stony heart,
To&H9; stab at half an hour of my life.
What, canst thou not forbear me half an hour?
Then get thee gone, and dig my grave thyself,
And bid the merry bells ring to&H4; thine ear,
That&H3; thou art crowned, not that&H3; I am dead:
Let all the tears that&H61; should bedew my hearse
Be drops of Balm, to&H9; sanctify thy head,
Only compound me with forgotten dust.
Give that&H62; which&H61; gave thee life, unto the worms,
Pluck down my officers, break my decrees,
For&H3; now a time is come to&H9; mock at Form:
Harry the fifth is crowned, up&H5; vanity,
Down royal state, all you sage counsellors, hence,
And to&H4; the English Court assemble now
From every region, apes of idleness:
Now neighbour confines, purge you of your scum
Have you a ruffian that&H61; will&H1; swear, drink, dance,
Revel the night, rob, murder, and commit
The oldest sins, the newest kind of ways?
Be happy, he will&H1; trouble you no&H2; more.
England shall double gild his treble gilt,
England shall give him office, honour, might:
For&H3; the fifth Harry, from curbed licence, plucks
The mussel of restraint, and the wild dog
Shall flesh his tooth on&H4; every innocent.
O my poor kingdom! sick with civil blows:
When that&H3; my care could not withhold thy riots,
What wilt thou do when riot is thy care?
O thou wilt be a wilderness again,
Peopled with wolves, thy old inhabitants.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: O pardon me, my liege, but for&H4; my tears,
The moist impediments unto my speech,
I had forestalled this dear and deep rebuke,
Ere you with grief had spoke, and I had heard
The course of it so&H51; far: there is your crown:
And he that&H61; wears the crown immortally,
Long guard it yours: if I affect it more,
Than as your honour, and as your renown,
Let me no&H2; more from this obedience rise,
Which&H61; my most inward true and duteous spirit,
Teacheth this prostrate and exterior bending,
God witness with me. When I here came in&H5;,
And found no&H2; course of breath within your majesty,
How cold it struck my heart! if I do fain,
O let me in&H4; my present wildness die,
And never live to&H9; show the incredulous world,
The noble change that&H61; I have purposed.
Coming to&H9; look on you, thinking you dead,
And dead almost, my liege, to&H9; think you were,
I spake unto this crown as having sense,
And thus upbraided it: the care on&H4; thee depending,
Hath fed upon&H4; the body of my father,
Therefore thou best of gold, art worse than gold,
Other less fine, in&H4; carat more precious,
Preserving life in&H4; medicine potable:
But thou, most fine, most honoured, most renowned,
Hast eat thy bearer up&H5;: thus my most royal liege,
Accusing it, I put it on&H4; my head,
To&H9; try with it as with an enemy,
That&H61; had before my face murdered my father,
The quarrel of a true inheritor,
But if it did infect my blood with joy,
Or swell my thoughts to&H4; any strain of pride,
If any rebel or vain spirit of mine,
Did with the least affection of a welcome,
Give entertainment to&H4; the might of it,
Let God for&H4; ever keep it from my head,
And make me as the poorest vassal is,
That&H61; doth with awe and terror kneel to&H4; it.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: God put in&H4; thy mind to&H9; take it hence,
That&H3; thou mightst win the more thy fathers love,
Pleading so&H51; wisely in&H4; excuse of it:
Come hither Harry, sit thou by&H4; my bed,
And hear (I think) the very latest counsel
That&H61; ever I shall breathe. God knows (my son)
By&H4; what by-paths, and indirect crooked ways,
I met this crown, and I myself know well,
How troublesome it sate upon&H4; my head:
To&H4; thee it shall descend with better quiet,
Better opinion, better confirmation,
For&H3; all the soil of the achievement goes,
With me into the earth, it seemed in&H4; me,
But as an honour snatched with boisterous hand,
And I had many living to&H9; upbraid
My gain of it, by&H4; their assistances,
Which&H61; daily grew to&H4; quarrel and to&H4; bloodshed,
Wounding supposed peace: all these bold fears
Thou seest with peril I have answered:
For&H3; all my reign hath been but as a Scene,
Acting that&H62; argument: and now my death
Changes the mood, for&H3; what in&H4; me was purchased,
Falls upon&H4; thee in&H4; a more fairer sort.
So&H3; thou the garland wearest successively,
Yet though thou standest more sure than I could do,
Thou art not firm enough, since griefs are green,
And all thy friends which&H61; thou must make thy friends,
Have but their stings and teeth newly taken out:
By&H4; whose fell working I was first advanced,
And by&H4; whose power I well might lodge a fear
To&H9; be again displaced: which&H61; to&H9; avoid,
I cut them off, and had a purpose, now
To&H9; lead out many to&H4; the Holy Land,
Lest rest, and lying still, might make them look,
Too near unto my state: therefore, my Harry,
Be it thy course to&H9; busy giddy minds
With foreign quarrels, that&H3; action hence borne out,
May waste the memory of the former days.
More would I, but my lungs are wasted so&H52;,
That&H3; strength of speech is utterly denied me:
How I came by&H4; the crown, O God forgive,
And grant it may with thee in&H4; true peace live.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: You won it, wore it, kept it, gave it me,
Then plain and right must my possession be,
Which&H61; I with more than with a common pain,
Against all the world will&H1; rightfully maintain.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Look, look, here comes my Iohn of Lancaster.

sp.speaker: Lanc.
sp.l: Health, peace, and happiness to&H4; my royal father.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thou bringest me happiness and peace son Iohn,
But health (alack) with youthful wings is flown
From this bare withered trunk: upon&H4; thy sight,
My worldly business makes a period:
Where is my lord of Warwicke?

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.l: My Lord of Warwicke.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Doth any name particular belong
Unto the lodging where I first did swoon?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: It is called Ierusalem, my noble Lord.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Laud be to&H4; God, even there my life must end.
It hath been prophesied to&H4; me many years,
I should not die, but in&H4; Ierusalem,
Which&H61; vainly I supposed the Holy Land:
But bear me to&H4; that&H62; chamber, there I will&H1; lie,
In&H4; that&H62; Ierusalem shall Harry die.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
By&H4; cock and pie sir, you shall not away tonight, what
Dauy I say?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: You must excuse me master Robert Shallow.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
I will&H1; not excuse you, you shall not be excused, excuses shall not be admitted, there is no&H2; excuse shall serve, you
shall not be excused: why Dauy.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Dauy, Dauy, Dauy, Dauy, let me see Dauy, let me see
Dauy, let me see, yea marry William Cooke, bid him come
hither, sir Iohn, you shall not be excused.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p:
Marry sir thus, those precepts cannot be served, and
again sir, shall we&Htp; sow the head land with wheat?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
With red wheat Dauy, but for&H4; William Cooke
are there no&H2; young pigeons?

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p:
Yes sir, here is now the Smiths note for&H4; shooing and
plough-irons.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Let it be cast and payed: sir Iohn, you shall not be excused.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p:
Now sir, a new link to&H4; the bucket must needs be
had: and sir, do you mean to&H9; stop any of VWilliams wages, about the sack he lost at Hunkly Fair?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
He shall answer it: some pigeons Dauy, a couple of
short legged hens, a joint of mutton, and any pretty little tiny
Kickshaws, tell william Cooke.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p: Doth the man of war stay all night sir?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Yea Dauy, I will&H1; use him well, a friend in&H4; the court is
better than a penny in&H4; purse: use his men well Dauy, for&H3; they are
arrant knaves, and will&H1; backbite.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p:
No&H2; worse than they are back-bitten sir, for&H3; they have
marvellous foul linen.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Well conceited Dauy, about thy business Dauy.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p:
I beseech you sir to&H9; countenance William Visor
of Woncote against Clement Perkes at the hill.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p:
There is many complaints Dauy against that&H62; Visor,
that&H62; Visor is an arrant knave on my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p:
I grant your worship that&H3; he is a knave sir: but yet
God forbid sir, but a knave should have some countenance at
his friends request, an honest man sir is able to&H9; speak for&H4; himself, when a knave is not: I have served your worship truly sir
this eight years and I cannot once, or twice in&H4; a quarter bear
out a knave against an honest man, I have little credit with your
worship: the knave is mine honest friend sir, therefore I beseech
you let him be countenanced.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Go to&H5; I say, he shall have no&H2; wrong, look about Dauy:
where are you sir Iohn? come, come, come, off with your boots,
give me your hand master Bardolfe.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: I am glad to&H9; see your worship.

sp.speaker: Shal
sp.p:
I thank thee with my heart kind master Bardolfe, and
welcome my tall fellow, come sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
I will&H1; follow you good master Robert Shallow: Bardolfe, look to&H4; our horses: if I were sawed into quantities, I
should make four dozen of such bearded hermits staves as
master Shallow: it is a wonderful thing to&H9; see the semblable
coherence of his men's spirits, and his, they, by&H4; observing him,
do bear themselves like&H4; foolish Justices: he, by&H4; conversing
with them, is turned into a Justice-like serving-man, their spirits
are so&H51; married in&H4; conjunction, with the participation of society,
that&H3; they flock together in&H4; consent, like&H4; so&H51; many wild-geese.
If I had a suite to&H4; master Shallow, I would humour his men
with the imputation, of being near their master: if to&H4; his
men, I would curry with master Shallow, that&H3; no&H2; man could
better command his servants. It is certain, that&H3; either wise
bearing, or ignorant carriage is caught, as men take diseases one
of another: therefore let men take heed of their company. I
will&H1; devise matter enough out of this Shallow, to&H9; keep prince
Harry in&H4; continual laughter, the wearing out of six fashions,
which&H61; is four terms, or two actions, and he shall laugh without
intervals. O it is much that&H3; a lie, with a slight oath, and
a jest, with a sad brow, will&H1; do with a fellow that&H61; never had
the ache in&H4; his shoulders: O you shall see him laugh till his face
be like&H4; a wet cloak ill laid up&H5;.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: I come master Shallow, I come master Shallow.

div2.stage: Enter Warwike, duke Humphrey,L. chiefe Iustice, Thomas Clarence, Prince, Iohn Westmerland.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: How now, my lord chief Justice, whither away?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: How doth the King?

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Exceeding well, his cares are now all ended.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: I hope not dead.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: He is walked the way of nature,
And to&H4; our&Htp; purposes he lives no&H2; more.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: I would his Majesty had called me with him:
The service that&H61; I truly did his life,
Hath left me open to&H4; all injuries.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Indeed I think the young King loves you not.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: I know he doth not, and do arm myself
To&H9; welcome the condition of the time,
Which&H61; cannot look more hideously upon&H4; me,
Than I have drawn it in&H4; my fantasy.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Here come the heavy issue of dead Harry:
O that&H3; the living Harry had the temper
Of he, the worst of these three gentlemen!
How many Nobles then should hold their places,
That&H61; must strike sail to&H4; spirits of vile sort?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: O God, I fear all will&H1; be overturned.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Good morrow cousin Warwicke, good morrow.

sp.speaker: Prin. ambo
sp.l: Good morrow cousin.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: We&Htp; meet like&H4; men that&H61; had forgot to&H9; speak.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: We&Htp; do remember, but our&Htp; argument
Is all too heavy to&H9; admit much talk.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Well, peace be with him that&H61; hath made us&Htp; heavy.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Peace be with us&Htp;, lest we&Htp; be heavier.

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: O good my lord, you have lost a friend indeed,
And I dare swear you borrow not that&H62; face
Of seeming sorrow, it is sure your own.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: Though no&H2; man be assured what grace to&H9; find,
You stand in&H4; coldest expectation,
I am the sorrier, would it were otherwise.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Well, you must now speak sir Iohn Falstaffe fair,
Which&H61; swims against your stream of quality.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Sweet princes, what I did, I did in&H4; honour,
Led by the impartial conduct of my soul.
And never shall you see that&H3; I will&H1; beg
A ragged and forestalled remission,
If truth and upright innocency fail me.
I will&H1; to&H4; the King my master that&H61; is dead,
And tell him who&H61; hath sent me after him.

sp.speaker: War.
sp.l: Here comes the Prince.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Good morrow, and God save your majesty.

sp.speaker: King Henry
sp.l: This new and gorgeous garment Majesty
Sits not so&H51; easy on&H4; me, as you think:
Brothers, you mixed your sadness with some fear,
This is the English, not the Turkish court,
Not Amurath an Amurath succeeds,
But Harry Harry: yet be sad, good brothers,
For&H3; by&H4; my faith it very well becomes you:
Sorrow so&H51; royally in&H4; you appears,
That&H3; I will&H1; deeply put the fashion on&H5;,
And wear it in&H4; my heart: why then be sad,
But entertain no&H2; more of it, good brothers,
Then a joint burden laid upon&H4; us&Htp; all,
For&H4; me, by&H4; heaven (I bid you be assured)
I will&H1; be your father, and your brother too,
Let me but bear your love, I will&H1; bear your cares:
Yet weep that&H3; Harries dead, and so&H52; will&H1; I,
But Harry lives, that&H62; shall convert those tears
By&H4; number into hours of happiness.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: We&Htp; hope no&H2; otherwise from your majesty.

sp.speaker: King Henry
sp.l: You all look strangely on&H4; me, and you most,
You are I think assured I love you not.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: I am assured, if I be measured rightly,
Your majesty hath no&H2; just cause to&H9; hate me.

sp.speaker: King Henry
sp.l: No&H7;? how might a prince of my great hopes forget,
So&H51; great indignities you laid upon&H4; me?
What, rate, rebuke, and roughly send to&H4; prison,
The immediate heir of England? was this easy?
May this be washed in&H4; lethe and forgotten?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: I then did use the person of your father,
The image of his power lay then in&H4; me,
And in&H4; the administration of his law,
Whiles I was busy for&H4; the common wealth,
Your Highness pleased to&H9; forget my place,
The majesty and power of law and justice,
The image of the King whom I presented,
And struck me in&H4; my very seat of judgment,
Whereon, (as an offender to&H4; your father,)
I gave bold way to my authority,
And did commit you: if the deed were ill,
Be you contented, wearing now the garland,
To&H9; have a son set your decrees at nought?
To&H9; pluck down Justice from your awful bench?
To&H9; trip the course of law, and blunt the sword,
That&H61; guards the peace and safety of your person?
Nay more, to&H9; spurn at your most royal image,
And mock your workings in&H4; a second body?
Question your royal thoughts, make the case yours,
Be now the father, and propose a son,
Hear your own dignity so&H51; much profaned,
See your most dreadful laws so&H51; loosely slighted,
Behold yourself so&H52; by a son disdained:
And then imagine me taking your part,
And in&H4; your power soft silencing your son,
After this cold considerance sentence me,
And as you are a King, speak in&H4; your state,
What I have done that&H61; misbecame my place,
My person, or my lieges sovereignty.

sp.speaker: King Henry
sp.l: You are right Justice, and you weigh this well,
Therefore still bear the Balance and the Sword,
And I do wish your honours may increase,
Till you do live to&H9; see a son of mine
Offend you, and obey you as I did:
So&H52; shall I live to&H9; speak my fathers words,
Happy am I that&H61; have a man so&H51; bold,
That&H61; dares do justice on&H4; my proper son:
And not less happy, having such a son,
That&H61; would deliver up&H5; his greatness so&H52;,
Into the hands of Justice you did commit me:
For&H4; which&H61; I do commit into your hand,
The unstained sword that&H61; you have used to&H9; bear,
With this remembrance, that&H3; you use the same
With the like&H2; bold, just, and impartial spirit,
As you have done against me: there is my hand,
You shall be as a father to&H4; my youth,
My voice shall sound as you do prompt mine ear,
And I will&H1; stoop and humble my intents,
To&H4; your well practised wise directions.
And princes all, believe me I beseech you,
My father is gone wild into his grave:
For&H3; in&H4; his tomb lie my affections,
And with his spirits sadly I survive,
To&H9; mock the expectation of the world,
To&H9; frustrate prophecies, and to&H9; race out,
Rotten opinion, who&H61; hath writ me down
After my seeming, the tide of blood in&H4; me
Hath proudly flowed in&H4; vanity till now:
Now doth it turn, and ebb back to&H4; the sea,
Where it shall mingle with the state of floods,
And flow henceforth in&H4; formal majesty.
Now call we&Hrp; our&Hrp; high court of parliament,
And let us&Hrp; choose such limbs of noble counsel,
That&H3; the great body of our&Hrp; state may go,
In&H4; equal rank with the best governed Nation,
That&H3; war, or peace, or both at once, may be,
As things acquainted and familiar to&H4; us&Hrp;,
In&H4; which&H61; your father shall have foremost hand:
Our&Hrp; coronation done, we&Hrp; will&H1; accite,
(As I before remembered) all our&Hrp; state,
And (God consigning to&H4; my good intents,)
No&H2; prince nor peer shall have just cause to&H9; say,
God shorten Harries happy life one day.

div2.stage: Enter sir Iohn, Shallow, Scilens, Dauy, Bardolfe, page.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Nay you shall see my orchard, where, in&H4; an arbour we&Htp;
will&H1; eat a last years pippin of mine own grafting, with a
dish of caraways and so&H52; forth: come cousin Scilens, and then
to&H4; bed.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Fore God you have here goodly dwelling, and rich.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Barren, barren, barren, beggars all, beggars all sir
Iohn, marry good air: spread Dauy, spread Dauy, well said
Dauy.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: This Dauy serves you for&H4; good uses, he is your serving-man, and your husband.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
A good varlet, a good varlet, a very good varlet sir
Iohn: by&H4; the mass I have drunk too much sack at supper: a
good varlet: now sit down, now sit down, come cousin.

sp.speaker: Scilens
sp.p:
A sirrah quoth a, we&Htp; shall do nothing but eat and
make good cheer, and praise God for&H4; the merry year, when
flesh is cheap and females dear, and lusty lads roam here
and there so&H51; merely, and ever among so&H51; merrily.

sp.speaker: sir Iohn
sp.p:
There is a merry heart, good M. Silens, I will&H1; give you a
health for&H4; that&H62; anon.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Give master Bardolfe some wine, Dauy.

sp.speaker: Dauy
Shal.
sp.p:
Be merry master Bardolfe, and my little soldier there,
be merry.

sp.speaker: Scilens
sp.p:
Be merry, be merry, my wife has all, for&H3; women are
shrews both short and tall, it is merry in&H4; hall when beards wags
all, and welcome merry shrovetide, be merry, be merry.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
I did not think master Scilens had been a man of this
mettle.

sp.speaker: Scilens
sp.p: Who&H62; I? I have been merry twice and once ere now.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p: There is a dish of Leather-coats for&H4; you.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Dauy?

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p:
Your worship: I will&H1; be with you straight, a cup of wine
sir.

sp.speaker: Scilens
sp.p:
A cup of wine that&H61; is brisk and fine, and drink unto
the leman mine, and a merry heart lives long a.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Well said master Scilens.

sp.speaker: Scilens
sp.p:
And we&Htp; shall be merry, now comes in&H5; the sweet of the
night.

sp.speaker: Falst
sp.p: Health and long life to&H4; you master Scilens.

sp.speaker: Scilens
sp.p:
Fill the cup, and let it come, I will&H1; pledge you a mile
to&H4; the bottom.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Honest Bardolfe, welcome, if thou wantest anything,
and wilt not call, beshrew thy heart, welcome my little tiny
thief, and welcome indeed too, I will&H1; drink to&H4; master Bardolfe,
and to&H4; all the cabileros about London.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p: I hope to&H9; see London once ere I die.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: And I might see you there Dauy!

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
By&H4; the mass you will&H1; crack a quart together, ha will&H1; you
not master Bardolfe?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Yea sir, in&H4; a pottle pot.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p:
By&H4; Gods liggens I thank thee, the knave will&H1; stick by&H4;
thee, I can assure thee that&H3; he will&H1; not out, a it is true bred!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: And I will&H1; stick by&H4; him sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p:
Why there spoke a King: lack nothing, be merry,
look who&H62; is at door there ho, who&H62; knocks?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: Why now you have done me right.

sp.speaker: Silens
sp.p: Do me right, and dub me Knight, samingo: is it not so&H52;?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: It is so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Silens
sp.p: Is it so&H52;, why then say an old man can do somewhat.

sp.speaker: Dauy
sp.p:
If it please your worship, there is one Pistoll come
from the court with news.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: From the Court? let him come in&H5;, how now Pistol?

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.p: Sir Iohn, God save you.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: What wind blew you hither Pistol?

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: Not the ill wind which blows no&H2; man to&H4; good:
sp.p:
sweet Knight, thou art now one of the greatest men in&H4; this
Realm.

sp.speaker: Silens
sp.p: Byrlady I think he be, but goodman Puffe of Barson.

sp.speaker: Pisto
sp.l: Puffe? Puffe ith thy teeth, most recreant coward, base,
sir Iohn, I am thy Pistol and thy friend, and helter skelter, have
I rode to&H4; thee, and tidings do I bring, and lucky joys, and golden times, and happy news of price.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p:
I pray thee now deliver them like&H4; a man of this
world.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: A foutre for&H4; the world and worldlings base, I speak
of Africa and golden joys.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: O base Assyrian Knight! what is thy news? let King
Couetua know the truth thereof.

sp.speaker: Scilens
sp.l: And Robin Hood, Scarlet, and Iohn.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: Shall dunghill curs confront the Helicons? and shall
good news be baffled? then Pistoll lay thy head in&H4; Furies lap.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Honest gentleman, I know not your breeding.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: Why then lament therefore.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Give me pardon sir, if sir you come with news from
the court, I take it there is but two ways, either to&H9; utter them, or
conceal them, I am sir under the King in&H4; some authority.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: Under which&H62; King, Besonian? speak, or die.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Under King Harry.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: Harry the fourth, or fifth?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Harry the fourth.

sp.speaker: Pist
sp.l: A foutre for&H4; thine office: sir Iohn, thy tender lambkin
now is King: Harry the fifths the man: I speak the truth: when
Pistol lies, do this, and fig me, like&H4; the bragging spaniard.

sp.speaker: Falst
sp.l: What is the old King dead?

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: As nail in&H4; door, the things I speak are just.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Away Bardolfe, saddle my horse, M. Robert Shallow,
choose what office thou wilt in&H4; the land, it is thine: Pistol, I will&H1;
double charge thee with dignities.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.l: O joyful day! I would not take a Knight for&H4; my fortune.

sp.speaker: Pistol
sp.l: What? I do bring good news.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Carry master Scilens to&H4; bed: master Shallow, my
lord Shalow, be what thou wilt, I am fortunes steward, get on&H5;
thy boots, we&Htp; will&H1; ride all night: O sweet Pistol, away Bardolf, come
Pistol, utter more to&H4; me, and withal, devise something to&H9; do
thyself good, boot, boot master Shallow, I know the young
King is sick for&H4; me: let us&Htp; take any man's horses, the laws of
England are at my commandment, blessed are they that&H61; have
been my friends, and woe to&H4; my Lord chief Justice.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Let vultures vile seize on&H4; his lungs also: where is the
life that&H61; late I led, say they, why here it is, welcome these pleasant days.

div2.stage: Enter Sincklo and three or foure officers.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
No&H7;, thou arrant knave, I would to&H4; God that&H3; I might
die, that&H3; I might have thee hanged, thou hast drawn my shoulder out of joint.

sp.speaker: Sincklo
sp.p:
The Constables have delivered her&H6; over to&H4; me,
and she shall have whipping cheer I warrant her&H6;, there hath
been a man or two killed about her&H6;.

sp.speaker: Whoore
sp.p:
Nut-hook, Nut-hook, you lie, come on&H5;, I will&H1; tell
thee what, thou damned tripe visaged rascal, and the child I go
with, do miscarry, thou wert better thou hadst struck thy mother, thou paper-faced villain.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
O the Lord, that&H3; sir Iohn were come! I would make
this a bloody day to&H4; somebody: but I pray God the fruit of
her&H2; womb miscarry.

sp.speaker: Sincklo.
sp.p:
If it do, you shall have a dozen of cushions
again, you have but eleven now: come, I charge you both
go with me, for&H3; the man is dead that&H61; you and Pistoll beat amongst you.

sp.speaker: Whoore
Sinck.
sp.p: Come, come, you she-knight-arrant, come.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
O God, that&H3; right should thus overcome might! well,
of sufferance comes ease.

sp.speaker: Whoore
sp.p: Come you rogue, come bring me to&H4; a justice.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I come, you starved blood-hound.

sp.speaker: Whoore
sp.p: Goodman death, goodman bones.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Thou Atomy, thou.

sp.speaker: Whoore
sp.p: Come you thin thing, come you rascal.

sp.speaker: Sinck.
sp.p: Very well.
More rushes, more rushes.
The trumpets have sounded twice.
It will&H1; be two o'clock ere they come from the coronation, dispatch, dispatch.

div2.stage: Trumpets sound, and the King, and his traine passe ouer the stage: after them enter Falstaffe, Shallow, Pistol, Bardolfe, and the Boy.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Stand here by&H4; me master Shallow, I will&H1; make the
King do you grace, I will&H1; leer upon&H4; him as he comes by&H5;, and
do but mark the countenance that&H61; he will&H1; give me.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: God bless thy lungs good Knight.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p:
Come here Pistoll, stand behind me. O if I had
had time to&H9; have made new liveries: I would have bestowed
the thousand pound I borrowed of you, but it is no&H2; matter, this
poor show doth better, this doth infer the zeal I had to&H9; see
him.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: It doth so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: It shows my earnestness of affection.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: It doth so&H52;.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: My devotion.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: It doth, it doth, it doth.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
As it were to&H9; ride day and night, and not to&H9; deliberate,
not to&H9; remember, not to&H9; have patience to&H9; shift me.

sp.speaker: Shal
sp.p: It is best certain:

but to&H9; stand stained with travail, and
sweating with desire to&H9; see him, thinking of nothing else, putting
all affairs else in&H4; oblivion, as if there were nothing else to&H9; be
done, but to&H9; see him.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p:
Tis semper idem, for, obsque hoc nihil est, it is in&H4; every
part.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: It is so&H52; indeed.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: My Knight, I will&H1; inflame thy noble liver, and make
thee rage, thy Dol, and Helen of thy noble thoughts, is in&H4; base
durance, and contagious prison, haled thither by&H4; most mechanical, and dirty hand: rouse up&H5; revenge from Ebony den, with
fell Alectoes snake, for&H3; Doll is in&H5;: Pistoll speaks nought but
truth.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.p: I will deliver her&H6;.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: There roared the sea, and trumpet Clangour sounds.

div2.stage: Enter the King and his traine.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.l: God save thy grace King Hall, my royal Hall.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: The heavens thee guard and keep, most royal imp of
fame.

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.l: God save thee, my sweet boy.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: My Lord chief justice, speak to&H4; that&H62; vain man.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Have you your wits? know you what it is you speak?

sp.speaker: Falst.
sp.l: My King, my Ioue, I speak to&H4; thee, my heart.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I know thee not old man, fall to&H4; thy prayers,
How ill white heirs becomes a fool and jester,
I have long dreamt of such a kind of man,
So&H51; surfeit-swelled, so&H51; old, and so&H51; profane:
But being awaked, I do despise my dream,
Make less thy body (hence) and more thy grace,
Leave gourmandising, know the grave doth gape
For&H4; thee, thrice wider than for&H4; other men,
Reply not to&H4; me with a fool-born jest,
Presume not that&H3; I am the thing I was,
For&H3; God doth know, so&H52; shall the world perceive,
That&H3; I have turned away my former self,
So&H52; will&H1; I those that&H61; kept me company:
When thou dost hear I am as I have been,
Approach me, and thou shalt be as thou wast,
The tutor and the feeder of my riots:
Till then I banish thee, on&H4; pain of death,
As I have done the rest of my misleaders,
Not to&H9; come near our&Hrp; person by&H4; ten mile:
For&H4; competence of life, I will&H1; allow you,
That&H62; lack of means enforce you not to&H4; evils,
And as we&Hrp; hear you do reform yourselves,
We&Hrp; will&H1; according to&H4; your strengths and qualities,
Give you advancement. Be it your charge, my lord,
To&H9; see performed the tenure of my word: set on&H5;.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p: Master Shallow I owe you a thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Yea marry sir Iohn, which&H61; I beseech you to&H9; let me have
home with me.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p:
That&H62; can hardly be, master Shalow: do not you grieve
at this, I shall be sent for&H5; in&H4; private to&H4; him, look you, he must
seem thus to&H4; the world: fear not your advancements, I will&H1;
be the man yet that&H61; shall make you great.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
I cannot perceive how, unless you give me your
doublet, and stuff me out with straw: I beseech you good sir
Iohn let me have five hundred of my thousand.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p:
Sir I will&H1; be as good as my word, this that&H61; you heard
was but a colour.

sp.speaker: Shall.
sp.p: A colour that&H61; I fear you will&H1; die in&H5; sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p:
Fear no&H2; colours, go with me to&H4; dinner:
Come lieutenant Pistol, come Bardolfe,
Enter Iustice and prince Iohn I shall be sent for&H5; soon at night.

sp.speaker: Iustice
sp.l: Go carry sir Iohn Falstalfe to&H4; the Fleet,
Take all his company along with him.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: My lord, my lord.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: I cannot now speak, I will&H1; hear you soon, take them
away.

l.foreign: Si fortuna me tormenta spero contenta.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: I like&H1; this fair proceeding of the Kings,
He hath intent his wonted followers
Shall all be very well provided for&H5;,
But all are banished till their conversations
Appear more wise and modest to&H4; the world.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: And so&H52; they are.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: The King hath called his parliament my lord.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: He hath.

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.l: I will&H1; lay odds, that&H3; ere this year expire,
We&Htp; bear our&Htp; civil swords and native fire,
As far as France, I heard a bird so&H52; sing,
Whose music, to&H4; my thinking, pleased the King:
Come, will&H1; you hence?

sp.speaker: Epilogue.
sp.p:
First my fear then my curtsy, last my speech.
My fear, is your displeasure, my curtsy, my duty, and my speech,
to&H9; beg your pardons: if you look for&H4; a good speech now, you
undo me, for&H3; what I have to say is of mine own making, and
what indeed (I should say) will&H1; (I doubt) prove mine own marring: but to&H4; the purpose, and so&H3; to&H4; the venture. Be it known to&H4;
you, as it is very well, I was lately here in&H4; the end of a displeasing play, to&H9; pray your patience for&H4; it, and to&H9; promise you a better: I meant indeed to&H9; pay you with this, which&H61; if like&H4; an ill venture it come unluckily home, I break, and you my gentle creditors loose, here I promised you I would be, and here I commit my body to&H4; your mercies, bate me some, and I will&H1; pay you
some, and (as most debtors do) promise you infinitely: and so&H3; I
kneel down before you; but indeed, to&H9; pray for&H4; the Queen.
If my tongue cannot entreat you to&H9; acquit me, will&H1; you
command me to&H9; use my legs? And yet that&H62; were but light
payment, to&H9; dance out of your debt, but a good conscience will&H1; make any possible satisfaction, and so&H52; would I: all
the Gentlewomen here have forgiven me, if the Gentlemen
will&H1; not, then the Gentlemen do not agree with the Gentlewomen, which&H61; was never seen in&H4; such an assembly.
One word more I beseech you, if you be not too much
cloyed with fat meat, our&Htp; humble Author will&H1; continue the
story, with sir Iohn in&H4; it, and make you merry with fair Katharine of France, where (for&H4; anything I know) Falstaffe
shall die of a sweat, unless already he be killed with your hard
opinions; for&H3; Olde-castle died Martyr, and this is not the
man: my tongue is weary, when my legs are too, I will&H1; bid
you, good night.
